within heaven and earth,
what is sufficient to detain my will!
Therefore, emptiness is
the abode of the Dao,
and simplicity is
the essence of the Dao.
Now, people serve their spirits and harass their essence,
busily striving and seeking externally.
These are all losses of their spiritual clarity and departures from their home.
Therefore, one who is freezing borrows extra clothing in spring,
and one suffering from heat stroke hopes for a cool breeze in autumn.
Surely, one who has an illness within must have a manifestation of it externally.
Now, the ash tree, already covered in green shadows,
and the cicada's shell, even more brightly illuminated,
these are all medicines for treating the eyes.
When someone seeks these things for no reason,
surely there is something obscuring their vision.
That which startles the world by the sage,
the True Man has never experienced;
that which rectifies the customs by the virtuous man,
the sage has never observed.
A puddle in an ox's hoofprint
will not contain a carp a foot long;
a mound-like hill
will not have timber ten feet tall.
Why is this so?
It is because their enclosures are narrow and small,
What they hold onto becomes unstable,
and they are excessively influenced by worldly customs.
The boundaries of what's proper are breached,
and internally, their clarity and brightness are muddied.
Therefore, they hesitate and waver until the end,
unable to find even a moment of tranquility and serenity.
Therefore, the sage cultivates the Way internally
and does not outwardly adorn himself with benevolence and righteousness.
He is not concerned with the pleasures of the ears and eyes
but wanders in the harmony of the spirit.
If one is like this,
he can measure the Three Springs below,
search the Nine Heavens above,
encompass the Six Directions,
and comprehend and connect all things.
This is the way of the sage.
As for the True Man,
his movements dissolve into the ultimate emptiness,
and he wanders in the realm of extinction.
He rides Feilian and follows Hundun,
gallops in the outer regions,
and cannot accommodate great size.
How much less can they contain that which has no enclosure!
Thus, their potential to become mountains and depths is far removed.
When people are confined by the world,
their form is necessarily bound, and their spirit leaks away,
therefore they cannot avoid emptiness.
If I can be tethered and restrained,
it must be that my fate resides outside of myself.
In the age of utmost virtue,
one is content to close one's eyes in the murky realm,
and strolls leisurely in the boundless universe,
holding up heaven and earth and entrusting oneself to the myriad things,
taking primordial chaos as one's pillar of support,
and drifting freely in the realm without boundaries or limits.
Therefore, the sage breathes in the breath of yin and yang,
and all living beings, without exception, look up expectantly,
relying on his virtue for harmony and obedience.
At this time,
there is no one to govern or manage them;
they separate and depart from their hidden obscurity and become complete on their own,
in a vast and boundless state,
their pure simplicity not yet dissipated,
diffused and blended into one,
and the myriad things are in great ease.
Therefore, even with Yi's knowledge, there is no use for it.
When the world declined,
it came to Fu Xi.
During the Xia Dynasty,
desires were connected to things,
intelligence was enticed by the external,
and the true nature of life was lost.
This influence extended to the Zhou Dynasty,
eroding purity and scattering simplicity,
departing from the Way with falsehood,
practicing frugality to cultivate virtue,
and thereby artifice and contrivance began to sprout.
When the Zhou Dynasty declined and the Kingly Way was abandoned,
the Confucians and Mohists then began to array their doctrines and debate,
dividing into factions and arguing.
Thereupon, extensive learning was used to cast doubt on sages,
flowery falsehoods were used to intimidate the masses,
stringed instruments were sung and drums were danced,
embellishing the *Book of Poetry*
and the *Book of Documents*,
in order to buy fame and reputation in the world.
Elaborate ascending and descending rituals
and adorned ceremonial robes and caps
could not be fully expressed even with the gathering of crowds,
and accumulating wealth was not enough to cover their expenses.
Thereupon, the myriad people began to be scattered and disunited,
each wanting to practice their own false knowledge,
in order to find a place in the world and wrongly choose fame and profit.
Therefore, the common people spread out on the banks of excess and wildness,
and lost the root of their fundamental nature.
The way in which the world loses its true nature
Decline gradually occurs;
the causes of it have been long in the making.
Therefore, the learning of the sage
seeks to return the nature to its beginning
and wander the mind in emptiness.
The learning of the enlightened person
seeks to connect the nature with vastness
and awaken to silence.
As for the learning of the common world, it is not like this.
Plucking virtue and seizing nature,
inwardly worrying the five viscera,
outwardly tiring the ears and eyes,
they then begin to attract the minutest details of things,
agitating and eliminating benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music,
displaying cruelty and surpassing wisdom throughout the world
in order to attract and hail fame and reputation in the world.
This is what I am ashamed of and will not do.
Therefore, rather than possessing the world,
it is better to possess an explanation;
and rather than possessing an explanation,
it is better to esteem the end and beginning of all things
and understand the boundaries between existence and non-existence.
Therefore, if the whole world praises him, he is not further encouraged;
if the whole world criticizes him, he is not further discouraged.
He is settled within the realm of life and death
and understands the principles of honor and disgrace.
Even if blazing fire and floods inundate the world,
the spirit remains undiminished within the breast.
If this is the case,
looking upon the affairs of the world,
is like seeing a flying feather or floating mustard seed;
how could one be willing to fussily make external things one's concern?
The nature of water is truly clear, yet earth muddies it;
human nature is originally peaceful, yet desires and cravings disorder it.
That which people receive from Heaven,
in terms of the ears and eyes in relation to sounds and sights,
the mouth and nose in relation to smells and tastes,
the skin in relation to cold and heat,
their underlying principle is the same.
Some communicate with spiritual enlightenment,
while others cannot avoid delusion and madness;
why is this?
It is because what controls them is different.
Therefore, the spirit is the source of wisdom,
when the spirit is clear, then wisdom is bright;
wisdom
is the storehouse of the mind,
when wisdom is impartial, then the mind is at peace.
People do not use flowing water as a mirror,
but use still water,
because of its stillness;
one does not see one's reflection in raw iron,
but sees one's reflection in a clear mirror,
It is because of its ease.
Indeed, only with ease and stillness,
can it form the characteristics and emotions of things.
Viewing it from this perspective,
that which is used must rely on that which is not used.
Therefore, an empty room generates light;
auspiciousness abides there.
Now, a clear mirror cannot be covered by dust,
and a clear spirit cannot be disturbed by desires.
If the spirit has already gone outward,
and affairs are reversed back upon it,
this is losing sight of the root
and seeking it in the branches.
If the external and internal do not correspond, yet one desires to connect with things,
obscuring one's mysterious light and seeking knowledge from the ears and eyes,
this is abandoning one's clear perception
and pursuing the obscure darkness.
This is called losing the Dao.
If the mind focuses on something, the spirit sighs there.
Returning it to emptiness will dissipate, melt away, and extinguish it.
This is the sage's wandering.
Therefore, the ancients in governing the world,
necessarily understood the true nature of human nature and destiny.
Their actions were perhaps not the same,
but their accordance with the Dao was one.
Now, not wearing fur in summer
is not out of dislike for it,
If one has excessive warmth for oneself.
That one does not use a fan on a winter day,
is not because one disdains it,
but because one already has sufficient coolness.
The sage eats according to the measure of his belly,
and clothes himself according to the measure of his form.
He is moderate in regard to himself.
How could a greedy and corrupt heart arise in him?
Therefore, he who is capable of possessing the world,
must be one who does not view the world as something to be possessed.
He who is capable of having a good reputation,
must be one who does not strive to seek it through actions.
The sage has something he has attained.
Having attained it, the desires and cravings of the heart are external to him.
The disciples of Confucius and
Mozi,
all used the techniques of benevolence and righteousness to teach and guide the world,
but they still could not avoid being constrained.
They themselves could not even put it into practice.
How much less so the things they taught?
Why is this?
Because their way is external.
To try to return to the root by starting with the branch,
even Xu You could not do it,
how much less so the common people!
If one truly understands the nature of one's being and life,
then benevolence and righteousness are naturally attached to it.
How can choosing or rejecting things be enough to disturb the mind?
As for the spirit, it has nothing to conceal;
the mind has nothing to burden it;
it is open, clear, and penetrating;
tranquil, indifferent, and without affairs;
without any congealing or stagnation;
empty and still, awaiting;
power and profit cannot entice it;
debaters cannot persuade it;
sounds and sights cannot seduce it;
beauty cannot corrupt it;
the wise cannot move it;
the brave cannot frighten it.
This is the roaming of the True Person.
If one is like this,
he molds and transforms the myriad things,
and becomes a companion to the Creator.
Within the space between Heaven and Earth,
within the universe,
nothing can cut him short or obstruct him.
For he who transforms into life does not die,
and he who transforms things is not transformed.
His spirit passes through Mount Li and
the Taihang Mountains without difficulty;
enters the four seas and nine rivers without getting wet;
dwells in small, narrow places without being obstructed;
and extends across the space between Heaven and Earth without being confined.
One who does not understand this,
even if his eyes can count flocks of thousands of sheep,
his ears can distinguish the tones of the eight winds,
his feet can tread the dance of "Yang A,"
and his hands can play the melody of "Green Stream,"
his wisdom encompasses heaven and earth,
his insight illuminates the sun and moon,
his eloquence can unravel linked rings,
and his words are as polished as jade,
it would still be of no benefit to governing the world.
Quietude and tranquility are the means to cultivate one's nature;
harmony, pleasure, and emptiness are the means to cultivate one's virtue.
If the external does not corrupt the internal,
then one's nature will obtain its proper state;
if one's nature is unmoved and harmonious,
then one's virtue will be secure in its position.
To cultivate life in order to manage the world,
to embrace virtue in order to complete one's years,
can be called truly embodying the Dao.
If this is the case,
the blood vessels will have no stagnation,
the five organs will have no suppressed energy,
misfortune and fortune will not be able to disturb or corrupt,
neither praise nor slander will be able to besmirch,
thus one will be able to reach the extreme.
If one does not have the era,
who can bring deliverance?
If one has the talent but does not meet the right time,
one's own self still cannot escape [difficulty],
how much more so if one is without virtue?
Moreover, human nature is such that
the ears and eyes respond to stimulation,
the heart and mind know sorrow and joy,
the hands and feet manipulate,
avoid the cold and heat,
and thereby interact with things.
When a bee or scorpion stings a finger, the spirit cannot be tranquil;
when a mosquito bites the skin, one's nature cannot be calm.
When worry and suffering arrive,
they disturb the human heart.
It is not merely the sting of bees and scorpions, or the biting of mosquitoes that is so distressing,
and yet you desire to be quiet, detached, empty, and non-existent,
how can this be?
One whose eyes discern the tip of an autumn hair [i.e., very small details],
their ears will not hear the sound of thunder.
One whose ears are attuned to the sound of jade stones,
their eyes will not see the shape of Mount Tai [i.e., a very large object].
Why is this?
It is because one is preoccupied with small things and forgets about the big things.
Now, when all things come [to us],
they pluck and pull at our nature,
seize and take away our emotions,
Like a flowing spring,
even if you wished not to draw from it,
how could you succeed?
Now, consider those who plant trees:
they water them with clear water,
and till them with fertile soil.
Ten people nurture them,
but one person pulls them up.
Surely, there will be no remaining saplings,
how much more so if the entire nation joins in felling them?
Even if you wished them to live long,
how could that be achieved?
Now, if a basin of water is in the courtyard,
and you try to clear it all day,
you may still not be able to see your eyebrows and eyelashes reflected in it.
But if you cloud it with just a single stir,
you will not be able to discern squareness or roundness.
Man's spirit is easily clouded and difficult to clear,
just like that basin of water.
How much more so if one stirs and muddies it for a whole lifetime,
how can one expect to have even a moment of tranquility?
In the ancient age of utmost virtue,
merchants found convenience in their shops,
farmers delighted in their work,
high officials were content in their positions,
and recluses followed their Way.
At this time,
wind and rain did not break or destroy,
grass and trees did not die prematurely,
the nine tripods were heavy (stable),
pearls and jade were lustrous and moist,
the *Dan Shu* (Red Book) emerged from the Luo River,
the *Lü Tu* (Green Chart) emerged from the Yellow River,
therefore Xu You,
Fang Hui,
Shan Juan,
and Pi Yi were able to attain their Dao (path).
Why is this?
Because the rulers of the world had a desire to benefit all under Heaven,
and therefore people were able to enjoy their leisure.
The talents of these four men
were not capable of being perfectly good,
but in this age,
there was no one who could share the same glory as them,
because they encountered the times of Tang (Yao) and
Yu (Shun).
By the time of Xia Jie
and Yin Zhou (紂),
they burned living people,
killed those who remonstrated,
built "cannon racks,"
cast metal pillars,
dissected the hearts of virtuous men,
split open the shins of talented scholars,
They minced the daughter of the Marquis of Gui,
and pickled the remains of Mei Bo.
At that time,
Mount Yao collapsed,
the three rivers dried up,
flying birds broke their wings,
and running beasts crippled their feet.
At that time,
could it be that there were no sages?
However, those who could not implement their Way
did not encounter the right era.
Even the heavenly bird flying a thousand fathoms above,
and the beast running in the thick undergrowth,
still suffered disaster,
how much more so the registered commoners?
From this, we can see that
embodying the Way does not depend solely on oneself,
but is also connected to the era.
The city of Liyang
was turned into a lake in one night;
the brave, strong, wise, and foolish, cowardly, and unworthy shared the same fate.
On Mount Wu,
lighting a fire with the wind,
the rich summer lingzhi mushroom and the artemisia all die together.
Therefore, the river fish cannot have clear eyes,
and the young crops cannot grow on time;
such is the nature of their environment.
Therefore, when the world is well-governed, the foolish cannot cause chaos alone;
when the world is in chaos, the wise cannot govern alone.
To be trapped in a turbid world
and blame the Way for not being practiced,
is like hobbling a fine steed
and expecting it to travel a thousand miles.
Now, with the pellet bow and machinery above,
and nets spread below,
even if one wishes to soar,
how could one possibly do so?
Therefore, the *Book of Poetry* says:
"Picking, picking cocklebur,
not filling the slanting basket.
Alas, I long for that man,
placing him on that Zhou road."
This is to express longing for a distant era.
*Treatise on Celestial Patterns*
When Heaven and Earth had not yet taken shape,
turbid and indistinct,
vast and boundless,
therefore it was called the Great Beginning (Tai Shi).
The Great Beginning produced Emptiness,
Emptiness produced the universe,
the universe produced primordial Qi.
Primordial Qi has boundaries;
the pure and Yang rose lightly and became Heaven,
the heavy and turbid congealed and became Earth.
The combination of pure and subtle is easy and swift,
the congealing of heavy and turbid is difficult and slow,
therefore Heaven was formed first and Earth was settled later.
The gathered essence of Heaven and Earth became Yin and Yang;
the focused essence of Yin and Yang became the four seasons;
the scattered essence of the four seasons became the myriad things.
Accumulated yang's hot qi, when prolonged, generates fire;
the essence of fire qi becomes the sun.
Accumulated yin's cold qi, when prolonged, becomes water;
the essence of water qi becomes the moon.
The excessive qi and essence of the sun and moon become the stars.
The heavens receive the sun, moon, and stars;
the earth receives water, floods, dust, and dirt.
In the past, Gonggong fought with Zhuanxu for the title of Emperor,
and in anger, he struck Buzhou Mountain,
causing the pillar of heaven to break,
and the cords of the earth to snap.
The heavens tilted to the northwest,
therefore the sun, moon, and stars moved there;
the earth was not full in the southeast,
therefore water, floods, dust, and dirt flow there.
The way of heaven is called round,
the way of earth is called square.
Square governs obscurity,
round governs brightness.
Brightness
is that which exhales qi,
therefore fire and the sun have an outward radiance.
Obscurity
is that which contains qi,
therefore water and the moon have an inward radiance.
That which exhales qi bestows,
Those that contain Qi transform.
Therefore, Yang bestows and Yin transforms.
The divergent Qi of Heaven and Earth,
when agitated, becomes wind;
the combined Qi of Heaven and Earth,
when harmonious, becomes rain.
When Yin and Yang mingle,
they interact to become thunder,
clash to become lightning,
and become disordered to become fog.
When Yang Qi prevails, it dissipates and becomes rain and dew;
when Yin Qi prevails, it congeals and becomes frost and snow.
Creatures with feathers and wings
are the flying kind,
therefore they belong to Yang.
Creatures with shells and scales
are the hibernating kind,
therefore they belong to Yin.
The sun
is the master of Yang,
therefore in spring and summer, the beasts shed their fur,
and at the summer solstice,
deer shed their antlers.
The moon is the ancestor of Yin,
therefore when the moon wanes, fish brains shrink,
and when the moon dies, shellfish become plump.
Fire ascends,
water flows downwards.
Therefore, birds move and fly high,
fish move and swim low.
Things of a kind move each other,
roots and branches correspond.
Therefore, the yangsui (burning mirror) facing the sun ignites and becomes fire,
the fangzhu (moon mirror) facing the moon condenses moisture and becomes water.
When a tiger roars, a valley wind arrives;
when a dragon rises, auspicious clouds gather.
When unicorns fight, the sun and moon are eclipsed;
when a whale dies, a comet appears.
When silkworms begin to spin silk, the shang string of a musical instrument breaks;
when a ben star falls, the Bohai Sea bursts its banks.
The ruler's emotions
communicate with Heaven above.
Therefore, when the tyrannical are punished, many whirlwinds arise;
when laws and decrees are distorted, many insects and caterpillars appear;
when the innocent are killed, the land becomes red;
when orders are not followed, there is much excessive rain.
The four seasons
are Heaven's officials;
the sun and moon
are Heaven's messengers;
the stars
These are the appointed times of Heaven;
rainbows, secondary rainbows, and comets
are the things Heaven dislikes.
Heaven has nine regions,
with nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine corners,
and is one hundred five million *li* away from the earth.
The five planets,
the eight winds,
the five offices,
the six treasuries,
the Purple Palace,
the Supreme Palace,
Xuanyuan,
Xianchi,
the Four Guardians,
the Milky Way.
What are the nine regions?
The central region is called Jun Heaven,
its stars are Horn,
Neck, and Root.
The eastern region is called Azure Heaven,
its stars are Room,
Heart, and Tail.
The northeastern region is called Changing Heaven,
its stars are Tail,
Winnowing Basket, Ladle,
The Oxherd.
The north is called Xuan Tian,
its stars are the Maid,
Emptiness, Danger,
Encampment.
The northwest is called You Tian,
its stars are Eastern Wall,
Stride, Bond.
The west is called Hao Tian,
its stars are Stomach,
Hairy Head, Net.
The southwest is called Zhu Tian,
its stars are Turtle Beak,
Three Stars, Eastern Well.
The south is called Yan Tian,
its stars are Transporting Ghosts,
Willow, Seven Stars.
The southeast is called Yang Tian,
its stars are Extended Net,
Wings, Chariot.
What are the Five Planets?
The east
is wood.
Its emperor is Taihao,
its assistant is Gou Mang,
who holds the compass and governs spring.
Its deity is the Jupiter,
Its beast is the Azure Dragon,
its note is *jiao*,
its days are *jia* and *yi*.
The South,
is fire.
Its emperor is Emperor Yan,
its assistant is Zhu Ming,
who holds the balance and governs summer.
Its spirit is the planet Mars,
its beast is the Vermilion Bird,
its note is *zhi*,
its days are *bing* and *ding*.
The Center,
is earth.
Its emperor is the Yellow Emperor,
its assistant is Houtu,
who holds the plumb line and controls the four directions.
Its spirit is the planet Saturn,
its beast is the Yellow Dragon,
its note is *gong*,
its days are *wu* and *ji*.
The West,
is metal.
Its emperor is Shao Hao,
its assistant is Rushou,
who holds the carpenter's square and governs autumn.
Its spirit is the planet Venus,
its beast is the White Tiger,
Its musical note is Shang;
Its days are Geng and Xin.
The north,
is water.
Its emperor is Zhuanxu;
Its assistant is Xuanming,
who holds power and governs winter.
Its spirit is the planet Mercury;
Its animal is the Black Tortoise;
Its musical note is Yu;
Its days are Ren and Gui.
When the Taiyin (Moon) is in the four midpoints (of the seasons),
then the planet Jupiter travels three constellations;
When the Taiyin is in the four "hooks" (corners of the year),
then the planet Jupiter travels two constellations.
Two times eight is sixteen;
Three times four is twelve;
Therefore, in twelve years it travels through twenty-eight constellations.
The sun travels one-twelfth of a degree each day;
Jupiter travels thirty degrees and seven-sixteenths of a degree each year;
In twelve years, it circles the heavens.
Mars regularly enters Taiwei in the tenth month, where it receives commands and proceeds to travel among the constellations.
It governs countries without the Dao,
bringing disorder and thieves,
disease and mourning,
famine and war.
Its appearances are unpredictable;
it changes and varies its color;
sometimes visible, sometimes hidden.
Saturn, beginning with Jia-yin in the first year, establishes its position in the Dipper constellation;
each year it resides in one lunar mansion.
If it should be residing there but does not,
that country will lose territory;
if it should not be residing there but does,
that country will gain land,
and the year will be bountiful.
It travels one twenty-eighth of a degree per day;
it travels thirteen and five one hundred and twelfth degrees per year;
it circles the heavens in twenty-eight years.
Venus, beginning with Jia-yin in the first month,
emerges as the morning star in the east with the Ying-shi constellation;
after two hundred and forty days it disappears;
after one hundred and twenty days it emerges as the evening star in the west;
after two hundred and forty days it disappears;
after thirty-five days it reappears in the east.
It emerges with Chen and Xu;
it disappears with Chou and Wei.
If it emerges when it should not emerge,
and disappears when it should not disappear,
the world will lay down its arms;
if it does not disappear when it should disappear,
and does not emerge when it should emerge,
the world will raise its armies.
The planet Mercury governs the four seasons.
It regularly aligns with the Kui and
Lou constellations at the spring equinox in the second month, with the Eastern Well and
Yugui constellations at the summer solstice in the fifth month,
with the Horn and
Kang constellations at the autumn equinox in the eighth month, and with the Dipper and
Cowherd constellations at the winter solstice in the eleventh month.
It emerges in the Chen and Xu directions
and disappears in the Chou and Wei directions.
It emerges for twenty days and then disappears.
In the morning, it is observed in the east;
in the evening, it is observed in the west.
If it does not appear in one season,
that season will be inharmonious.
If it does not appear in all four seasons,
there will be a great famine throughout the land.
What are the Eight Winds?
Forty-five days after the winter solstice, the Tiaofeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Tiaofeng wind, the Mingshufeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Mingshufeng wind, the Qingmingfeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Qingmingfeng wind, the Jingfeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Jingfeng wind, the Liangfeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Liangfeng wind, the Changhefeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Changhefeng wind, the Buzhoufeng wind arrives.
Forty-five days after the arrival of the Buzhoufeng wind, the Guangmofeng wind arrives.
When the Tiaofeng wind arrives, release minor prisoners and
resolve pending cases.
When the Bright and Common Wind arrives, then regulate the boundaries and
cultivate the fields.
When the Pure and Bright Wind arrives, then send out gifts of silk and jade,
dispatching them to the feudal lords.
When the Great Wind arrives, then ennoble those with positions and
reward those with merit.
When the Cool Wind arrives, then repay the virtue of the Earth and
sacrifice to the four directions.
When the Changhe Wind arrives, then collect taxes from the districts, and
zithers and lutes are not played.
When the Northwest Wind arrives, then repair palaces and buildings, and
fortify the border walls.
When the Vast and Silent Wind arrives, then close the passes and bridges, and
execute punishments and sentences.
What are the Five Offices?
The east is for agriculture,
the south is for the Sima (Minister of War),
the west is for governance,
the north is for the Sikong (Minister of Public Works),
the center is for the capital.
What are the Six Treasuries?
Zi and Wu,
Chou and Wei,
Yin and Shen,
Mao and You,
Chen and Xu,
These correspond to Si and Hai.
Taiwei is
the court of Taiyi.
Zigong is
the dwelling of Taiyi.
Xuanyuan is
the abode of the emperor's consorts.
Xianchi is
the park of the water balance.
Tianhe is
the gate of the multitude of gods.
The Four Guardians
are what are used to administer rewards and punishments.
Taiwei governs the Red Bird.
Zigong holds the Dipper and rotates to the left,
the sun travels one degree per day,
to complete a circuit of the heavens.
At the winter solstice, the sun enters the Junlang mountains,
the sun moves one degree per day,
the moon travels 182 and 5/8 degrees,
and at the summer solstice, it is at the head of the Ox mountain.
Repeating, 365 and 1/4 degrees complete one year.
Taiyi begins the origin;
in the first month, Jian Yin,
the sun and moon both enter five degrees of Ying Shi.
Tianyi begins the construction; after 76 years,
the sun and moon again enter five degrees of Ying Shi in the first month without any remainder,
It is named one Ji (紀, cycle).
Twenty Ji in total,
a great cycle of 1520 years comes to an end.
After three cycles,
the sun, moon, and stars return to the beginning of Jia-yin (甲寅).
The sun travels one degree in the Wei (危) constellation each day,
and the year has a surplus of one-fourth of a degree.
Therefore, every four years, 1461 days accumulate and coincide again.
Thus, after eighty years, it returns to the previous day.
Zi-wu (子午) and
Mao-you (卯酉) are the two cords,
Chou-yin (丑寅),
Chen-si (辰巳),
Wei-shen (未申),
Xu-hai (戌亥) are the four hooks.
Northeast is the dimension of requital of virtue,
Southwest is the dimension of turning away from the sun,

To determine due east and west,
first erect a pole in the east,
hold another pole and move ten paces away from the first pole,
and use it to observe the sun as it begins to rise from the northern edge.
When the sun directly enters (sets),
set up another gnomon in the east.
Use the western gnomon to observe the sun entering the northern corner of the west,
then determine the midpoint between the two eastern gnomons,
together with the western gnomon;
this determines the true east and west.
At the winter solstice,
the sun rises in the southeastern corner
and sets in the southwestern corner.
Until the Spring
and Autumn equinoxes,
the sun rises due east
and sets due west.
At the summer solstice,
it rises in the northeastern corner
and sets in the northwestern corner.
Until then, it is due south.
To know the numerical extent of east-west and north-south distances,
set up four gnomons in a square, one *li* apart.
A little more than ten days before or after the Spring or Autumn equinox,
from the northern gnomon at a distance, observe the first appearance of the sun at dawn,
waiting for correspondence.
When they correspond, this is when it is directly aligned with the sun.
Immediately use the southern gnomon to observe it.
Use the number of inches the sun appears to enter the front gnomon as the divisor,
and divide the assumed width.
Determining the distance between the gnomon's shadow (表) and its height (袤)
allows us to know the number of li from this point east and west.
Suppose when observing the sunrise,
the shadow enters one inch in front of the gnomon,
this inch represents one li.
One li accumulates to 18,000 inches,
so from here it is 18,000 li eastward.
Observing when the sun is about to set,
the shadow enters half an inch in front of the gnomon,
then half an inch represents one li.
Dividing one li by half an inch,
accumulating inches yields 36,000 li,
dividing then gives the number of li westward from here.
Combine these,
the number of li east and west,
is the diameter of the Earth.

Observing the sun from the southwest marking post,
the sun begins to emerge at the summer solstice aligning with the north marking post.

Directly east is 18,000 *li*,

Double this,
and you have the number of *li* from north to south.
For numbers not taken from the middle,
add or subtract the number of *li* based on the extent of protrusion or recession relative to the front marker.
If the marker recedes one *cun*,
subtract one *li* for the sun's proximity.
If the marker protrudes one *cun*,
add one *li* for the distance.
If you wish to know the height of the heavens,
set up a post one *zhang* high.
Precisely north-south distance is one thousand *li*.
On the same day, measure the shadows.
The shadow of the north post is two *chi*,
the shadow of the south post is one *chi* and nine *cun*.
This means that southwards, for every thousand *li*, the shadow shortens by one *cun*.
At 20,000 *li* south, there will be no shadow,
meaning it is directly beneath the sun.
Since a shadow of two *chi* yields a height of one *zhang*,
south one part yields a height of five parts.
Therefore, take the number of *li* from here south to the point directly beneath the sun,
and multiply it by five,
making 100,000 *li*.
Then the height of the sky is great.
If the gnomon's shadow and the gnomon's height are equal,
then the height is equal to the distance.

Heaven is one, Earth is two, Man is three;

Eight nines make seventy-two;
Two governs even numbers;
even numbers support odd numbers;

Seven nines make sixty-three;

Six times nine is fifty-four;

Seven governs the stars;

Two times nine is eighteen;
Eight governs the wind;

The azure sky was mended,

Backing square continents,

the things where yin and yang were blocked and stagnant, unable to flow,

At this time,
lying down in a sprawled manner,

Their gait was stumbling,

None know from whence they came into being,

The Way of the True Man is hidden,

His actions were contrary to Heaven,

The ruler dwelt in his position but felt no peace,

Therefore, ruler and minister were estranged and not intimate,

The planted communal trees wither and split open;

In the time of the late era,
The Seven Kingdoms were of different lineages,
The feudal lords established their own laws,
Each having different customs;
[They] moved horizontally and vertically among each other,
Raising armies and engaging in mutual conflict,

Thousands of miles away,

Servants and grooms,

on long and distant roads,

men weakened and carts broken down,
mud reaching up to their knees,

The so-called "states annexing fallen ones" involves

Therefore, the world comes to the point where people use heads as pillows,

Thus, from the Three Dynasties onward,

The feudal lords forcefully wage war,

But reaching the present time,

Those nearby offer their wisdom,

With hands folded in obeisance and with pointing and gesturing,

Spring, Autumn, Winter, Summer

All under Heaven was blended and made as one.
Sons and grandsons succeeded each other.
This is how the Five Emperors welcomed the virtue of Heaven.
Now, a sage

He assists and supports the capable,

did not use reins or bits
He was known throughout the world for his skill in charioteering.
Fu Xi and Nüwa

Why is this?
It is because they embodied utmost emptiness, purity, and unity,

The *Zhou Shu* says:

Now, the way Shen Buhai, Han Fei, and Shang Yang governed

They devised the five punishments,
engaging in carving and cutting,

They cut down the people,

This is like carrying firewood to put out a fire,

If you plant an *yang* tree in a well, it will not even be able to accommodate a pot;
if you plant a *tiao* tree in a ditch, it will not even be able to accommodate a boat;

What is the reason for this?
It is that they are all wild sprouts without roots.
The Yellow River, though it turns nine times before flowing into the sea,

Stagnant water that is not drained

It is like Houyi requesting the elixir of immortality from the Queen Mother of the West,

Because they do not know from whence the elixir of immortality comes.
Therefore, begging for fire is not as good as obtaining a tinder,
and relying on borrowed water is not as good as digging a well.
Spiritual Instructions
In ancient times, before there was heaven and earth,

obscure and dim,

vast and boundless,

Two spirits were born in chaos,
managing heaven and building earth,
Vast and indistinct, unknowable as to its end;
surging and boundless, unknowable as to its cessation.
Therefore, Yin and Yang were differentiated,

The firm and the yielding complemented each other,

Therefore, the spirit (精神)
is what Heaven possesses;
while bones and frame

The spirit enters its gate,
and the bones and frame return to their root.
What of me then remains?
Therefore, the sage emulates Heaven and follows natural feelings,
not bound by customs,

He takes Heaven as his father,
and Earth as his mother,
Yin and Yang as his guiding principle,

Heaven is tranquil, hence clear;

The myriad things that lose these die;
those that follow these live.
Now, stillness and silence
Spirit is the dwelling place of the divine;
emptiness and nothingness

gain it externally.

Now, the spirit is
what is received from Heaven;
and the physical body is

Therefore, it is said:

Therefore, it is said that in the first month there is congealed fat,

In the eighth month it stirs,

The form and body are thus completed,
the five viscera are then shaped.
Therefore, the lungs govern the eyes,
the kidneys govern the nose,
the gall bladder governs the mouth,

The exterior is the surface, and the interior is the lining;
opening and closing, expanding and contracting,

Therefore, the roundness of the head resembles Heaven,
the squareness of the feet resembles Earth.
Heaven has four seasons,
five elements,
nine divisions,

man also has four limbs,
five viscera,
nine orifices,

Heaven has wind, rain, cold, and heat;

Therefore, the gall bladder is like clouds,
the lungs are like air,
the spleen is like wind,
the kidneys are like rain,
The liver is like thunder,
and is thus connected to Heaven and Earth,

Therefore, the ears and eyes
are like the sun and moon,
and the blood and qi

In the sun there is a three-legged crow,

If the sun and moon lose their proper course,

if the wind and rain are not on time,
they will cause destruction and disaster;
if the five planets lose their proper course,

Now, the Way of Heaven and Earth
is extremely vast and great,

How can human ears and eyes endure constant labor and exertion without rest for long?

Therefore, blood and qi
are the splendor of a person;
and the five viscera
are the essence of a person.
If blood and qi can concentrate on the five viscera and not dissipate outwards,

When the chest and abdomen are full, and desires are lessened,
then the ears and eyes become clear,

When the ears and eyes are clear,

it is called "brightness."
If the five organs can all be subordinate to the heart without discord,
then firm will prevails, and conduct does not become perverse.
When firm will prevails, and conduct does not become perverse,
then spirit is abundant, and qi does not dissipate.
When spirit is abundant, and qi does not dissipate, then there is order (理),
with order there is balance (均),
with balance there is unobstructedness (通),
with unobstructedness there is spirit-like (神) quality,
with spirit-like quality, in seeing, there is nothing that is not seen,
in hearing, there is nothing that is not heard,
in action, there is nothing that is not accomplished.
Therefore, worries and troubles cannot enter,

Therefore, there are matters that, sought for beyond the four seas, cannot be found,

Thus, that which is sought for in abundance yields little,

Now, the orifices are
the windows and doors of the spirit;
and the blood and qi are
the messengers of the five organs.
If the ears and eyes indulge in the pleasures of sounds and sights,

If the five viscera are shaken and unsettled,

If the blood and qi surge uncontrollably and without rest,

If the spirit gallops outward and is not guarded,

If the ears and eyes are sharp, clear, profound, and free from allurement and craving,

Therefore, it is said:

This speaks of how the spirit must not be allowed to indulge outwardly.
Therefore, excessive colors confuse the eyes,

excessive sounds bombard the ears,

excessive flavors confuse the mouth,

To choose or reject things so as to please the mind,

these four things

Therefore, it is said:
Desires cause one's vital energy to dissipate,

then your will and energy will be exhausted day by day.
Why is it that people cannot complete their natural lifespan and instead die prematurely by execution or punishment?
What is the reason?
It is because of their attachment to life.
Only those who can act without concern for life
are able to cultivate and obtain life.
Heaven and earth operate and communicate with each other,

If you can know the One,
then there is nothing that you will not know;
if you cannot know the One,

Consider my place in the world:

In the interaction of things with things,

However,
my being born,

Perhaps life is servitude,

The world is vast,

My being born is not forcibly sought,

Desiring life without working for it,
hating death without refusing it,
despising it without hating it,

In my life, I have a seven-foot form;

My life compared to things with form

Therefore, my life does not increase the number of things,

How can I know what to rejoice in and what to detest, what is beneficial and what is harmful in the midst of all this?
The Creator's grasping and drawing of things is

When it is in the stagnant pool,

Grief and joy

Therefore, it is said:

The spirit is serene and boundless,

Therefore, the heart

Examine what is without flaw,

At rest, they do not know what to do,

Like the radiance of light,
like the emission of a shadow,
To regard Dao as the guiding principle

Embrace the fundamental nature of Great Purity

Consider life and death as a single transformation,

Repeating the cycle from beginning to end,
Not knowing its origin,

One rests in a corner without constraints,

Dwelling without confinement,

To let the spirit wander freely without losing its fullness,
Day and night, without injury, he makes spring with things;

Equalize death and life,
Then his will will not be daunted.
By agreeing with the transformations,

The perfect man relies on an unshakeable pillar,

Such a man
embraces simplicity and guards his essence,
molting like a cicada, shedding skin like a snake,
He wandered in the Great Clarity,
lightly rising and going alone,
suddenly entering the darkness.
The phoenix cannot compare with him,
how much less the small sparrow!
How could power, position, titles, and emoluments be enough to encompass his will!
Yanzi made a covenant with Cui Zhu,
facing death and not changing his principles.
Zhi and Hua were about to fight and die,
the Duke of Ju offered generous bribes to stop them,
but they did not change their course.
Therefore, Yanzi could be influenced with benevolence,
but could not be coerced with weapons;
Zhi and Hua could be stopped with righteousness,
but could not be enticed with profit.
A gentleman dies for righteousness,
and cannot be kept back with wealth and honor;
he acts for righteousness,
and cannot be frightened by death.
They simply acted for righteousness,
and even they were not constrained by material things,
how much more so those who embrace non-action!
Yao did not consider possessing the empire as valuable,
therefore he passed it on to Shun;
Gongzi Zha did not consider possessing a state as honorable,
therefore he declined the throne.
Zihan did not consider jade as wealth,
Therefore, he did not accept the treasure;
Wu Guang did not harm his integrity for the sake of living,
therefore, he threw himself into the abyss.
From this perspective,
the greatest nobility does not depend on titles,
and the greatest wealth does not depend on possessions.
The world is extremely vast,
yet he gave it to another;
his own person is extremely close,
yet he abandoned it in the abyss.
Beyond this,
nothing else is worth pursuing.
This is what is meant by a person without burdens.
A person without burdens
does not consider the world to be valuable.
Examining the discourse of the ultimate person above,
and deeply investigating the meaning of morality,
then comparing it to the actions of the world below,
it is indeed shameful.
Therefore, understanding Xu You's intentions,
the *Jin Teng*
and *Bao Tao* are abandoned;
Yanling Jizi did not accept the state of Wu,
and those who argued over fields were ashamed;
Zihan did not profit from precious jade,
and those who fought over contracts were embarrassed;
Wu Guang was not sullied by the world,
and those who greedily seek profit and steal life were disheartened.
Therefore, those who do not observe the great principles
do not know that life is not worth coveting.
Those who do not hear grand words
do not know that the world is not worth profiting from.
Now, consider a village gathering in a remote, crude place.
They strike pots and tap tiles,
harmonizing and singing,
considering themselves happy.
Try striking a large drum for them,
and striking a great bell.
Then, they will begin to be taken aback
and realize that their pots and tiles are shameful.
To possess the *Book of Poetry* and
the *Book of Documents*,
cultivate learning,

Those who do not value the world
are like those who have learned the large drum.
Esteemed position and great profit
are what people covet.
If you were to have them hold a map of the world in their left hand while slitting their own throat with their right,
even a foolish person would not do it.
Judging from this,
life is more valuable than the world.
A sage's food is enough to sustain his vital energy,
and his clothing is enough to cover his form.
Contentment seeks nothing more;
Without possession of the world, one's nature suffers no loss;
With possession of the world, one does not envy harmony.
Possessing the world,
Not possessing the world,
Is essentially the same thing.
Now, regarding a granary (敖倉) of the Gan people,
And giving people river water,
Feeding them when hungry,
Giving them drink when thirsty,
What enters their bellies is merely a basket of food and a ladle of soup.
Then, the body is satiated, and the granary does not diminish because of it;
The belly is full, and the river water does not dry up because of it.
Having it does not increase satiety,
Not having it does not cause hunger.
This is essentially the same as guarding one's grain bin and
Owning one's well.
It is essentially the same.
Great anger damages the yin,
Great joy causes the yang to decline,
Great worry causes internal collapse,
Great fear produces madness.
Removing impurities and discarding burdens,
Being indifferent as if one had not yet emerged from the source,
Is then considered great penetration.
Clearing the eyes but not using them to see,
Quieting the ears but not using them to listen,
Closing the mouth but not using it to speak,
Entrust the heart without using thought,
abandon cleverness and return to Great Simplicity,
let the spirit rest and discard knowledge and experience,
be awake yet as if dozing,
be alive yet as if dead,
in the end, return to the origin, the time before birth,
and become one with Transformation.
Death and life
are one body.
Now, those laborers,
raising hoes and shovels,
carrying baskets of earth,
with salty sweat intermingling,
and panting breaths pressing on their throats,
at such a time,
if they can rest in the shade,
they will be greatly delighted.
The space within caves and grottoes
is not just the rest of shade.
Those with illnesses and internal disorders,
clutch at their hearts and press on their stomachs,
knock their heads on their knees,
huddled up and attentive,
unable to sleep the whole night.
At such a time,
if they can happily fall asleep,
their relatives and brothers will be joyfully delighted.
Now, the peace of a long night,
is not merely the joy of one good meal.
Therefore, knowing the vastness of the universe,
one cannot be threatened with life and death;
knowing the harmony of nurturing life,
one cannot be enticed with the empire;
knowing the joy before birth,
one cannot be frightened by death;
knowing that Xu You was more esteemed than Shun,
one is not greedy for possessions.
The wall standing,
is not as good as its collapse,
how much more so is not building the wall in the first place!
The ice congealing,
is not as good as its melting,
how much more so is not forming ice in the first place!
From nothing, there is existence;
from existence, there is nothing;
beginning and end have no limit;
no one knows where it originates.
Without penetrating both outer and inner,
who can be without likes and dislikes?
The outside of the outside is
the utmost greatness;
the inside of the inside is
the utmost nobility;
being able to know the great nobility,
where can one go and not succeed!
Those who study in a declining age
do not know to return to the original heart and root,
but directly carve and polish their nature,
forcibly alter their feelings,
in order to interact with the world.
Therefore, even though the eyes desire something,
they are restrained by measure;
even though the heart delights in something,
it is controlled by propriety.
In movement and conduct,
bending and bowing humbly,
meat is congealed and not eaten,
wine is clarified and not drunk.
Externally, their form is bound;
internally, their virtue is worried.
They disrupt the harmony of yin and yang
and oppress the feelings of their inherent nature,
therefore, they are sad people their whole lives.
Those who understand the ultimate Dao are not like this.
They regulate their feelings and nature,
manage their mental techniques,
nourish themselves with harmony,
and maintain themselves with suitability.
They delight in the Dao and forget their lowliness;
they are content with virtue and forget their poverty.
If their nature has desires,
they have no desire that is not attained;
When the heart is not happy,
there is no pleasure that is not pursued.
What is not beneficial to one's feelings is not allowed to burden one's virtue.
What is not conducive to one's nature is not allowed to harm one's harmony.
Therefore, one can indulge the body and let loose the will,
yet the standards and measures set forth can be a model for the world.
Now, those Confucian scholars,
do not address the source of their desires but forbid their desires.
They do not investigate the origin of their pleasures but shut off their pleasures.
This is like blocking the source of a river with one's hand.
Those who govern the people
are like raising birds and beasts.
If they do not block their enclosures
and allow them to have wild hearts,
and instead bind their feet
to restrict their movement,
yet wish for them to cultivate life and live out their full span,
how can this be possible?
Now, Yan Hui,
Ji Lu,
Zi Xia,
and Ran Boniu
were all accomplished students of Confucius.
Yet Yan Yuan died young,
Ji Lu was minced in Wei,
Zi Xia lost his sight,
and Ran Boniu suffered from leprosy.
All these are cases of forcing one's nature and going against one's feelings, thus failing to attain harmony.
Thus, Zixia saw Zengzi,
one time emaciated and another time stout.
Zengzi asked him the reason for this.
He replied:
"When I go out, I see the pleasure of wealth and nobility and desire it;
when I come in, I see the Way of the former kings and also delight in it.
The two battle in my heart,
therefore I am emaciated.
When the Way of the former kings prevails,
therefore I am stout."
Extending this,
the aspiration is not that one is incapable of coveting wealthy and noble positions,
or disinclined to luxurious and extravagant pleasures,
but that one directly forces one's nature and suppresses one's desires,
using righteousness to defend oneself.
Even though one's emotional heart is repressed and stifled,
and one's physical nature is bent and exhausted,
one still has no choice but to force oneself,
therefore one cannot reach the end of one's natural lifespan.
As for the perfect person,
they eat according to the measure of their belly,
dress according to the measure of their body,
roam according to the space for their body,
act according to the suitability of their feelings,
have surplus of the world and do not covet,
abandon the myriad things and do not seek profit;
dwell in the vast expanse of the universe,
To wander in the boundless fields,
to ascend the Grand Zenith,
to rely on the Great Oneness,
to play with Heaven and Earth within one's grasp—
how could one then be concerned with wealth or poverty, stoutness or leanness?
Therefore, the Confucian is not able to prevent people from having desires,
but rather, though they desire, they are able to restrain themselves.
He is not able to prevent people from having pleasures,
but rather, though they take pleasure, they are able to prohibit themselves from excess.
To make the world fear punishment and dare not steal,
how could that compare to being able to cause there to be no thieving heart?
The Yue people obtain the bearded snake,
and consider it a superior dish.
The people of the Central Kingdom obtain it and discard it, finding no use for it.
Therefore, knowing that it has no use,
the greedy person is able to refuse it.
Not knowing that it has no use,
even the upright person cannot decline it.
The reason why a ruler ruins and destroys his state,
abandons his altars of soil and grain,
dies at the hands of others,
and is laughed at by the world,
has never been anything other than because of uncontrolled desires.
The ruler of Chou lost his state because he coveted a large bell as a bribe.
The lord of Yu coveted the jade disc from Chuiji and was captured.
Duke Xian was charmed by the beauty of Li Ji and brought chaos upon four generations.
Duke Huan was addicted to Yi Ya's seasonings and was not buried in a timely manner.
A barbarian king indulged in the pleasure of music and women, and lost his territory.
If these five rulers
had indulged their feelings and rejected excess,
using themselves as the standard,
not being swayed by external things,
how could they have encountered such great calamities?
Therefore, for an archer,
it is not that he fails to hit the target without arrows,
but a student of archery does not focus on making the arrows;
for a charioteer, the chariot does not move without reins,
but a student of charioteering does not focus on making reins.
Knowing that a fan in winter
or fur in summer is useless to oneself,
then the changes of all things become like dust.
Therefore, to stop boiling water with hot water,
the boiling will not stop;
truly knowing the root cause,
then removing the fire is all that is needed.
The fundamental principle instructs
the governance of Taiqing,
which is harmonious and tranquil,
genuine and simple,
calm and not restless,
changing without contrivance,
inwardly conforming to the Dao,
outwardly harmonizing with righteousness,
when initiated, it results in refinement,
Their actions are swift and beneficial to things,
their words are concise and follow principle,
their conduct is unconstrained and accords with feelings,
their hearts are joyful and without deceit,
their affairs are simple and without embellishment.
Therefore, they do not choose auspicious times,

At peace, they stop;
stimulated, they act.
Their whole being is in harmony with heaven and earth,

Therefore, heaven covers them with virtue,
earth supports them with joy,
the four seasons do not lose their order,
wind and rain do not bring their violence,

At this time,
the dark and primordial energy arrives, touches, and illuminates,
phoenixes and unicorns arrive,

sweet dew descends,
bamboo seeds fill,
When yellow dye comes forth,

Mechanical devices and deceitful falseness

But when it comes to a declining age,

engrave gold and jade,

The Qilin (Chinese unicorn) does not roam.

Human implements are insufficient,

And of the flourishing sprouts, buds, eggs, and embryos of the myriad things that fail to come to fruition,

They pile up earth to make hills,
fertilize fields to plant grain,
dig the earth to drink from wells,
dredge rivers for profit,
build cities for defense,
If wild animals are captured and kept as livestock,

Thunder and lightning will cause destruction and breakage,

The fields and thickets will be overgrown with weeds,

of the herbs and trees, the budding sprouts,

Furthermore, in summer houses and palatial structures,

hibiscus, water caltrop, and lotus,

Even if you, O king, made no mistakes in your carving and sawing,

the rivers,

beasts with hooked claws,

The harmony of heaven and earth,

Qi rises up and steams,

Forty-six days after the Winter Solstice,

Earth holds Qi but has not yet released it,
Yin and Yang store and give,

to nurture and brew

Therefore, when spring is austere and autumn flourishes,

From this perspective,
Heaven and Earth, the universe,

within the six directions,
The punishment of one person.
Therefore, those who are clear about their nature,

Thus, the sage
knows the distant by means of the near,

The ancients

Therefore, righteousness is valued.
The emotions of yin and yang,

Men and women living together in mixed company without distinction,

The emotions regarding life and destiny,
indulging and threatening each other,

Therefore, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music,

Benevolence

righteousness

ritual

When the divine intelligence is settled in the world, the heart returns to its original state.
When the heart returns to its original state, the people's nature is good.
When the people's nature is good, then heaven and earth, yin and yang, accordingly encompass them,
then wealth is sufficient.
When wealth is sufficient, then people are prosperous.
Greed, baseness, anger, and strife cannot arise.
Viewing it from this,
then benevolence and righteousness would be unnecessary.

The "Diao Yu"

Therefore, only after knowing the spirits does one realize that morality is insufficient.
Only after knowing morality does one realize that benevolence and righteousness are insufficient to practice.
Only after knowing benevolence and righteousness does one realize that rituals and music are insufficient to cultivate.
Now, turning one's back on the root and seeking it in the branches,

one cannot be spoken to about the ultimate.
The greatness of heaven and earth

The movements of the stars and moon,

the sound of thunder,

the changes of wind and rain,

Therefore, that which is greatly visible,
can be measured;
that which is clearly seen,
can be obscured;
that which is heard,
can be tuned;
that which can be observed in color,

But that which is the greatest,
Heaven and Earth cannot contain it;
that which is the smallest,

Once calendars were established,

Once benevolence and righteousness were established,

Once artificiality arises,

If one employs deception to skillfully rise above others,

Yao Guang,

Relieving the distressed and impoverished,

Promoting benefit and eliminating harm,

Though virtuous, there was no place to establish their merit.

encompasses Heaven and Earth,
