yet they fail to recognize the worth of those who are their contemporaries and do the same things.
It is not that their talents are inferior,
but that the times are not appropriate.
Therefore, even swift steeds like the six Qi horses or the Siyi Jue Ti horses,
when crossing rivers,
are not as useful as a hollow log,
because the situation dictates it.
Therefore, those who establish merit
are simple in their actions but cautious regarding the times.
The common people of today,
consider success in achievement as wisdom,
consider overcoming trouble as intelligence,
consider encountering hardship as foolishness,
consider dying for principle as stubbornness.
I believe they are merely pursuing their respective extremes.
Prince Bi Gan
surely knew that he could avoid harm by letting his hair down and feigning madness,
yet he delighted in acting uprightly, exhausting his loyalty, and dying for principle,
therefore he did not do it.
Bo Yi and Shu Qi
surely could have accepted emolument and held office
in order to achieve merit,
yet they delighted in separating themselves from the world and acting against the grain to cut themselves off from the masses,
therefore they did not strive for it.
Xu You and Shan Juan
surely could have comforted the world and pacified the seas
in order to benefit the people with their virtue,
yet they were ashamed to corrupt their harmony with material things,
therefore they did not accept it.
Yu Rang and Yao Li
surely knew that they could enjoy their families, secure their wives and children,
and steal a life of ease,
yet they delighted in offering their sincerity and fulfilling their vows
by dying for their lords,
therefore they did not linger.
Now, viewing Bi Gan from the perspective of Ji Zi,
he seems foolish;
viewing Ji Zi from the perspective of Bi Gan,
he seems base;
viewing Bo Yi from the perspective of Guan Zhong and Yan Ying,
he seems simpleminded;
viewing Guan Zhong and Yan Ying from the perspective of Bo Yi,
they seem greedy.
Their choices differ,
their desires are opposed,
and each enjoys his own pursuits.
Who then should be made to judge them?
Zengzi said:
"Striking a boat in the water,
birds hear it and soar high,
fish hear it and hide deep."
Therefore, what they pursue differs,
and each obtains what is convenient for them.
Thus, Huizi followed with a hundred carriages
to pass through Mengzhu,
Zhuangzi saw him and
abandoned his remaining fish.
The pelican drinks several pecks of water and is still not satisfied,
the eel and sturgeon die when a drop enters their mouths,
Zhi Bo possessed the three Jin states and his desires were still not met,
Lin Lei and Rong Qiqi
wore clothes like hanging straw but their intentions were not unsatisfied.
Viewing it from this perspective,
Then their pursuits and conduct would each be different.
Why should they criticize each other?
Those who value life do not consider personal gain or loss.
Those who uphold integrity do not seek to evade difficulties.
Those who crave emolument disregard their own safety when they see profit.
And those who cherish reputation do not obtain things unrighteously.
These are arguments for each other,
like ice and charcoal, hooks and ropes.
When will they ever be compatible?
If a sage is placed in the middle,
then he can encompass and possess all of them,
and there will be no right or wrong to judge.
Birds rely on nests,
foxes rely on dens.
The one who makes a nest
completes the nest and then is able to roost there.
The one who makes a den
completes the den and then is able to rest there.
Pursuing and abandoning, conducting oneself righteously,
is also where people roost and rest.
Each finds joy in what they are comfortable with,
achieving what they aim for,
which is called being a complete person.
Therefore, those who discuss things with the Dao
unify and harmonize them.
The way to govern a state is that
the ruler has no harsh decrees,
Officials are without troublesome governance;
scholars are without false conduct;
artisans are without excessive ingenuity.
Their affairs are orderly and without disturbance;
their implements are complete and without embellishment.
It is not so in a chaotic age.
Those who cultivate conduct expose each other to appear superior;
those who practice ritual vie with each other in hypocrisy.
Carriages and carts are excessively carved and polished;
utensils and implements are hastily engraved and inlaid.
Those who seek wealth contend for rare and difficult-to-obtain things, regarding them as treasures.
Those who disparage learning dwell in vexation and turmoil, regarding it as wisdom.
They compete in deceitful arguments,
which accumulate for a long time without resolution,
being of no benefit to governance.
Artisans create strange implements,
which take years to complete,
and are not practical for use.
Therefore, the method of Shen Nong says:
"If a man is strong and mature but does not plow,
there will be someone in the world who suffers from hunger because of it.
If a woman is of age but does not weave,
there will be someone in the world who suffers from cold because of it."
Therefore, he personally plowed
and his wife personally wove,
setting an example for the world.
In guiding the people,
he did not value rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,
Not being a vessel [means] being a useless thing.
Therefore, those whose plowing is not strong
have nothing with which to nourish their lives.
Those whose weaving is not vigorous
have nothing with which to cover their bodies.
Having a surplus or lacking enough
each returns to his own person.
When clothing and food are abundant and overflowing,
treachery and evil do not arise,
[the people] are peaceful and happy without incident,
and the world is at peace.
Therefore, Confucius and Zeng Shen
have no place to apply their goodness,
Meng Ben and Cheng Jing
have no place to exercise their power.
The customs of a declining age
are characterized by knowledge, skill, deceit, and falsehood.
They embellish the multitude with useless things,
value goods from distant places,
treasure rare and hard-to-obtain wealth,
and do not accumulate the means to nourish life.
They corrupt the purity of the world,
divide the simplicity of the world,
and restrain oxen and horses with halters and yokes as if in prison.
They confuse the people,
turn clarity into turbidity,
and [the people's] nature and lives become unrestrained, all disordered by pursuits.
When integrity and sincerity are dissipated and overflow,
people lose their true feelings and nature.
Consequently, there are kingfisher feathers and rhinoceros ivory, and elaborate embroidered patterns
to confuse their eyes;
penned-up livestock and millet and sorghum,
and fragrances from Jing and Wu
to sate their mouths;
bells and drums, pipes and flutes,
silk and bamboo, metal and stone
to corrupt their ears;
pursuing or abandoning (things), acting according to righteousness,
ritual propriety, and slanderous criticism
to preoccupy their minds.
Consequently, the common people are confused and agitated, their customs in chaos,
pursuing profit day and night,
fretful, grasping, and shallow.
Law conflicts with righteousness,
conduct is contrary to profit.
Even ten Guan Zhongs
could not govern them.
Moreover, the wealthy ride in carriages and wear embroidered brocade clothing,
their horses adorned with ivory and yak-tail ornaments;
the curtains and mats
are of patterned silk and embroidered ribbons,
blue and yellow intermingled,
making it impossible to describe completely.
The poor in summer wear coarse hemp and rope belts,
They chew on beans and drink water to fill their stomachs,
in order to withstand the summer heat;
in winter, they take apart their sheepskin coats,
and their short, coarse clothes do not cover their bodies,
so they warm themselves by the stove's opening.
Therefore, their status as registered commoners is no different from others,
yet the difference between their poverty and wealth
is like that between a ruler and a slave;
it is beyond comparison.
Those who rely on strange skills and engage in devious practices
can provide for themselves in their own time;
those who uphold righteousness and follow reason,
not engaging in opportunistic gains,
cannot avoid the suffering of hunger and cold;
and to want the people to abandon the superficial and return to the fundamental
is like opening up the source while blocking the stream.
Furthermore, carving and engraving
are harmful to agricultural affairs;
brocade embroidery and gathering silk threads
are detrimental to women's work.
When agricultural affairs are abandoned
and women's work is harmed,
that is the root of hunger and the source of cold.
When hunger and cold arrive together,
that one can avoid breaking the law and incurring punishment
has never been heard of in ancient or modern times.
Therefore, benevolence and baseness depend on the times,
Success or failure does
not depend on ability; profit or harm
depends on fate, not on wisdom.
Consider the soldiers of a defeated army:
the brave and martial flee,
and the general cannot stop them.
The ranks of a victorious army:
even the timid advance to their death,
fearing that they cannot escape.
Therefore, when a river bursts its banks and flows, an entire village,
fathers, sons, and brothers
abandon each other and flee,
struggling to ascend hills and slopes,
to climb high mounds.
The swift-footed go first,
unable to care for each other.
When the world is happy and intentions are calm,
seeing people from neighboring countries drowning,
one still feels pity for them,
how much more so for relatives!
Therefore, when one is safe, kindness extends to neighboring countries,
but intentions are extinguished by it.
When one is in danger, one forgets even one's relatives,
and benevolence cannot resolve the situation.
A swimmer cannot rescue a drowning person
if his own hands and feet are in distress.
A burned person cannot extinguish a fire
if his own body is in pain.
When the people have a surplus, they yield;
when they lack, they contend.
Yielding gives rise to propriety and righteousness;
contention gives rise to violence and disorder.
One who knocks on the door to ask for water or fire,
there is no one who will refuse.
because they have plenty to spare.
Firewood is not sold in the forest,
fish are not hawked by the lake,
because there is a surplus of everything.
Therefore, when goods are abundant, people desire simplicity;
when the means of support are sufficient, contention ceases.
In the time of the King of Qin,
some pickled their own children,
because profit was insufficient.
When the Liu family held power,
even the lone man collected the orphan,
because wealth was abundant.
Therefore, when the world is well-governed, petty men adhere to righteousness,
and profit cannot tempt them;
when the world is in chaos, gentlemen commit wickedness,
and the law cannot prohibit them.
*Dao Ying Xun*
Taiqing asked Wuqiong:
"Do you know the Dao?"
Wuqiong said:
"I do not know."
Again, he asked Wuwei, saying:
"Do you know the Dao?"
Wuwei said:
"I know the Dao."
He said:
"Does your knowledge of the Dao also have a measure?"
Wuwei said:
"My knowledge of the Dao has a measure."
He said:
"What is its measure?"
Wuwei said:
"My knowledge of the Dao is that it can be weak,
can be strong;
can be gentle,
can be firm;
can be Yin,
can be Yang;
can be deep,
can be bright;
can encompass Heaven and Earth,
can respond to all directions.
This is how I know the measure of the Dao."
Taiqing again asked Wushi, saying:
"Earlier,
I asked Wuqiong about the Dao,
and Wuqiong said:
'I do not know it.'
He further inquired of Wuwei.
Wuwei said:
"I know the Dao."
He said:
"You know the Dao.
Does your knowing of the Dao also have limits?"
Wuwei said:
"My knowing of the Dao has limits."
He said:
"What are its limits?"
Wuwei said:
"My knowing of the Dao is that it can be weak,
it can be strong;
it can be soft,
it can be hard;
it can be Yin,
it can be Yang;
it can be obscure,
it can be clear;
it can encompass heaven and earth,
it can respond and adapt without limit.
This is how I know the limits of the Dao."
"If this is so,
then is Wuwei's knowledge, or Wuqiong's non-knowledge,
which is right, which is wrong?"
Wushi said:
"Non-knowledge is deep,
while knowledge is shallow.
Non-knowledge is internal,
while knowledge is external.
Non-knowledge is refined,
while knowledge is coarse."
Taiqing looked up to the sky and sighed, saying:
"Then is not-knowing actually knowing?"
Is knowing actually not-knowing?
Who knows that knowing is actually not-knowing?
That not-knowing is actually knowing?"
Wu Shi said:
"The Dao cannot be heard;
to hear it is to be wrong.
The Dao cannot be seen;
to see it is to be wrong.
The Dao cannot be spoken;
to speak it is to be wrong.
Who knows the form of the formless?"
Therefore, Laozi said:
"When the whole world knows good as good,
this is already not good."
Therefore,
"Those who know do not speak;
those who speak do not know."
That is [the truth].
Bai Gong asked Confucius, saying:
"Can one have subtle words with a person?"
Confucius did not answer.
Duke Bai said:
"If one throws a stone into water,
what will happen?"
Someone replied:
"The skillful divers of Wu and
Yue can retrieve it."
Duke Bai said:
"If one throws water into water,
what will happen?"
Confucius said:
"When the waters of Zi and
Mian merge,
Yi Ya could taste it and know."
Duke Bai said:
"In that case, is it really impossible to have subtle conversations with people?"
Confucius said:
"Why should it be impossible!
It depends on whether they understand the meaning of words!
Those who understand the meaning of words
do not use words to speak.
Those who fight for fish get wet;
those who chase beasts run;
it's not that they enjoy it.
Therefore, the highest words discard words;
the highest action is inaction.
What shallow knowledge disputes is
trivial!"
Duke Bai did not understand,
therefore he died in the bathroom.
Therefore Laozi said:
"Words have a source,
affairs have a lord.
It is only because they are ignorant,
that they do not understand me."
This refers to Bai Gong.
Huizi made laws for the state for King Hui,
and after they were completed, he showed them to the people,
and the people all approved of them.
He presented them to King Hui,
and King Hui was very pleased with them.
He showed them to Zhai Jian,
and Zhai Jian said,
"Good!"
King Hui said,
"Good,
can it be implemented?"
Zhai Jian said,
"No."
King Hui said,
"It is good, but cannot be implemented,
why?"
Zhai Jian replied,
"Now, when people lift a large piece of timber,
those in the front shout 'Heave ho!',
and those in the back respond,
this is a song to encourage strength in lifting heavy objects.
Is it not possible to use the exciting music of Zheng and
Wei, or the Chu melodies?
However, the reason why they are not used is
because they are not as suitable as this.
Governing a state lies in ritual propriety,
not in literary debates."
Therefore, Laozi said:
"The more laws and ordinances are promulgated,
the more thieves and robbers there will be."
This is what he meant.
Tian Pian used the Daoist arts to persuade the King of Qi,
and the King of Qi responded, saying:
"What I possess
is the state of Qi.
Daoist arts are difficult to remove troubles,
I wish to hear about the administration of the state of Qi."
Tian Pian replied:
"My words do not deal with administration,
but they can be used for administration.
It is like a forest without timber,
but it can be used as timber.
I hope the king will discern what I mean
and derive the administration of the state of Qi from it himself.
Even if it cannot remove his troubles,
within heaven and earth,
within the six directions,
It can be molded and transformed.
The affairs of the state of Qi,
what is there to ask about!
This is what Lao Dan called
"the form of formlessness,
the image of nothingness."
This is it.
If what the king asks about is
Qi,
what Tian Pian praises is
talent.
Talent does not reach the forest,
the forest does not reach the rain,
the rain does not reach yin and yang,
yin and yang do not reach harmony,
harmony does not reach the Dao."
Bai Gong Sheng obtained the state of Jing,
but could not distribute its treasury to the people.
After seven days,
Shi Qi entered and said:
"Gaining it through unrighteousness,
and furthermore being unable to distribute it in charity,
calamity will surely arrive.
Unable to give it to the people,
it would be better to burn it,
lest people harm me with it."
Bai Gong did not listen.
After nine days,
Lord Ye entered,
and then opened the treasury of Taifu to give to the masses,
took out the soldiers from the Gao storehouse to assign to the people,
and then attacked him.
After nineteen days, Bai Gong was captured.
To desire to possess a state that is not one's own
is the height of greed.
Unable to benefit others,
and furthermore unable to benefit oneself,
is the height of foolishness.
The stinginess of Duke Bai
—how is it different from the owl loving its offspring?
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"To hold and fill to overflowing
is not as good as stopping.
To hammer and sharpen to a point
cannot be long preserved."
Zhao Jianzi chose Xiangzi as his successor.
Dong Eyu said:
"He is of lowly origin; why
is he now being made the successor?"
Jianzi said:
"It is because of his character;
he can endure shame for the sake of the state."
Another day,
Zhi Bo was drinking with Xiang Zi and slapped Xiang Zi's head.
An officer requested to kill Zhi Bo,
but Xiang Zi said,
"When the former ruler established me,
he said I could endure shame for the sake of the state.
Did he say I could assassinate people!"
After ten months,
Zhi Bo besieged Xiang Zi at Jinyang.
Xiang Zi broke through the ranks and attacked him,
greatly defeating Zhi Bo,
and broke his head to make a drinking vessel.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said,
"Know the male,
keep to the female,
and be the ravine of the world."
Nie Que asked Bei Yi about the Dao.
Bei Yi said,
"Correct your form,
unify your gaze,
and the harmony of Heaven will arrive.
Gather in your knowledge,
correct your measurements,
and the spirit will come to dwell.
Virtue will become your beauty,
and the Dao will become your abode.
Be foolish, like a newborn calf,
and do not seek its origin."
Before the words were finished,
Nie Que fell asleep,
and then continued in a daze.
He put on his clothes, sang a song, and left, saying:
"His form is like withered bones,
his heart is like dead ashes.
He truly knows reality,
and does not cling to the old ways.
Dark and boundless,
there is no one to consult with his mind.
Who is he?"
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Understanding and penetrating in all directions,
can one be without knowledge?"
Zhao Xiangzi sent someone to attack the Di and defeated them,
capturing Zuo Ren
and Zhong Ren.
An envoy came to see him,
and Xiangzi was about to eat but had a worried look on his face.
Those around him said:
"Two cities have fallen in one morning,
this is what people rejoice about.
Now you have a worried look,
why?"
Xiangzi said:
"The Yangtze
and Yellow Rivers are large,
but they do not last more than three days.
Sudden winds and heavy rain
do not last a moment in the middle of the day.
Now the virtue of the Zhao clan has not accumulated,
and two cities have fallen in one morning,
Will ruin not reach us?"
Confucius heard this and said,
"The Zhao clan will flourish!"
For worry
is the means to flourishing,
while joy
is the means to ruin.
Victory is not the difficult part;
maintaining it
is the difficult part.
A wise ruler uses this to maintain victory,
therefore their blessings extend to later generations.
Qi, Chu,
Wu, and Yue all once had victories,
but ultimately met their destruction,
because they did not understand how to maintain victory.
Only a ruler with the Way is able to maintain victory.
Confucius had the strength to lift a city gate barrier,
but refused to be known for his strength.
Mozi defended against attacks,
and Gongshuban yielded,
but he refused to be known for his military expertise.
Those skilled at maintaining victory
make the strong appear weak.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"The Tao is empty,
and in being used, it is never filled."
When Hui Meng saw King Kang of Song,
King Kang stamped his feet and cleared his throat,
and said in a harsh voice:
"What I admire
are the brave and the strong;
I do not admire those who practice benevolence and righteousness.
With what will you teach me?"
Hui Meng replied:
"I have a way here
to make it so that even if a man is brave,
a thrust will not penetrate;
even if he is strong,
a blow will not hit.
Does Your Majesty have no interest in this?"
King Song said:
"Excellent!
This is what I desire to hear."
Hui Meng said:
"To thrust and not penetrate,
to strike and not hit,
this is still a form of disgrace.
I have a way here
to make it so that even if a man is brave, he will not dare to thrust;
even if he is strong, he will not dare to strike.
Not daring to thrust,
not daring to strike,
is not because he lacks the intention.
I have a way here..."
to make people fundamentally lack that intention.
Lacking that intention
means they have no heart of love or benefit.
I have a way in this
to make all the men and women in the world joyfully have a heart of love and benefit.
This is more virtuous than courage and strength;
it is above four layers of accumulation.
Does Your Majesty alone have no intention of this?”
The King of Song said,
“This is what I desire to obtain.”
Hui Meng replied,
"It is Kongzi and Mozi.
It is so.
Kong Qiu
and Mo Di,
without land, became rulers;
without office, became leaders;
all the men and women in the world stretched their necks and raised their heels, wishing to be safe and benefit from them.
Now Your Majesty
is the ruler of ten thousand chariots.
If you truly have that aspiration,
then everyone within the four borders will obtain benefit from it.
This man is much wiser than Confucius and
Mozi!"
The King of Song had no reply.
After Hui Meng left,
the King of Song said to his attendants:
"He is eloquent;
the guest has used his words to overcome me!"
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Courage in daring leads to death;
courage in not daring leads to life."
From this perspective,
great courage turns out to be a form of non-courage.
In the past, Yao had nine assistants,
Shun had seven assistants,
and King Wu had five assistants.
Yao, Shun,
and King Wu, among these nine,
seven, and five men,
could not do a single thing,
yet they folded their hands and received success,
because they were good at leveraging the resources of others.
Therefore, if a man races a Jun horse on foot, he cannot win against the Jun horse,
but if he rides in a chariot, even the Jun horse cannot win against the man.
In the north, there is a beast,
its name is Jue,
with a rat's front and a rabbit's rear,
it stumbles when it tries to walk,
When it walks, it stumbles.
It constantly has the *qióngqióng* and *jùxū* fetch sweet grass to give it.
If it falls and suffers harm,
the *qióngqióng* and *jùxū* will certainly carry it away.
This is using what they are capable of
to support what it is incapable of.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"He who carves in place of the master craftsman
rarely does not injure his hand."
Bo Yi advised Lord Si of Wei on the art of kingship.
Lord Si responded to him, saying:
"What I possess
is a thousand chariots;
I wish to receive your teachings with them."
Bo Yi replied, saying:
"If Wu Huo can lift a thousand jun,
how much more so one jin!"
Du He advised Lord Zhaowen of Zhou on pacifying the world.
Lord Zhaowen said to Du He:
"I wish to learn how to pacify Zhou."
Du He replied, saying:
"If what I say is not feasible,
then it cannot pacify Zhou.
If what I say is feasible,
then Zhou will pacify itself.
This is what is meant by pacifying without pacifying."
Therefore, Laozi said:
“The greatest carving leaves no mark.
Therefore, though many carriages are made to carry, there is no carriage."
The law of the State of Lu was that
if a Lu person became a slave to the feudal lords,
anyone who could redeem them
could take gold from the treasury.
Zigon redeemed Lu people from the feudal lords,
but when he returned, he declined to receive the gold.
Confucius heard of this and said:
"Si has made a mistake!
The actions of a sage
can change customs and transform morals,
and the lessons can be applied to later generations;
they are not merely for personal conduct.
Now, in the State of Lu, the rich are few and the poor are many.
If one redeems a person and accepts gold,
it is considered dishonorable;
if one does not accept gold,
then people will no longer redeem others.
From now on,
the people of Lu will no longer redeem people from the feudal lords."
Confucius can truly be said to understand transformation.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Seeing the small is called clarity."
Marquis Wu of Wei asked Li Ke:
"What was the reason for the downfall of Wu?"
Why is that?"
Li Ke replied,
"He fought many battles and won many victories."
Marquis Wu said,
"To fight many battles and win many victories
is a blessing for the state.
That he alone caused its downfall,
what is the reason?"
Li Ke replied,
"Frequent battles exhaust the people,
frequent victories make the ruler arrogant.
For an arrogant ruler to employ exhausted people,
and the state *not* to perish,
is rare under Heaven.
Arrogance leads to license,
license leads to the exhaustion of resources;
exhaustion leads to resentment,
resentment leads to the exhaustion of thought.
When both ruler and ruled are exhausted,
Wu's demise was already late in coming!
This is why Fucha took his own life at Gansui."
Therefore, Laozi said:
"When功成名遂 (merit is achieved and fame is established),
to retire
is the Way of Heaven."
Ning Yue desired to serve Duke Huan of Qi,
but being impoverished, he had no way to make himself known.
Thereupon he became a merchant,
pushing a cart,
intending to trade in Qi,
spending the night outside the city gate.
Duke Huan was in the suburbs welcoming guests,
opening the gate at night,
clearing the carts aside,
the torches were very bright,
and the followers were numerous.
Ning Yue was eating under an ox cart,
saw Duke Huan and became sad,
struck the ox horn and sang a merchant's song rapidly.
Duke Huan heard it,
and touching his servant's hand said:
"Strange,
this singer is no ordinary person!"
He ordered a following cart to carry him.
Duke Huan returned,
and his followers requested to see him,
Duke Huan gave him clothes and a hat and met him.
Ning Qi met him,
and persuaded him with matters concerning the whole world.
Duke Huan was very pleased,
and was about to appoint him,
but the ministers disputed this, saying:
"He is a guest,
a man from Wei.
Wei is not far from Qi,
You would be better off sending someone to inquire about him.
If, upon inquiry, he is indeed a worthy man,
employing him would not be too late."
Duke Huan said:
"That is not right.
If I inquire,
I would worry about discovering some minor fault in him.
To forget a man's great merits because of his minor faults
is how rulers lose the scholars of the world."
In general, all listening must have verification;
to listen once and not inquire further
is to agree with what is said.
Furthermore, it is inherently difficult for people to be perfect;
simply weigh and employ their strengths.
In this selection,
Duke Huan understood it.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Heaven is great,
Earth is great,
the Way is great,
and the King is also great.
Within the realm there are four greats,
and the King occupies one of them."
This is to say that he is able to encompass everything.
Great King Danfu lived in Bin,
and the Di people attacked him.
He served them with leather, silk, pearls, and jade, but they would not accept it,
It is said:
"What the Di people seek is
land, not for the sake of wealth and possessions."
King Danfu said:
"Living with a man's elder brother and killing his younger brother,
living with a man's father and killing his son,
I cannot bear to do such a thing.
All of you, strive to stay where you are!
Being my subjects,
what is the difference between being subjects of the Di people?
Moreover, I have heard it said,
'Do not harm what is being nourished for the sake of what is used to nourish it.'"
Leaning on his staff, he departed,
and the people linked together and followed him,
and consequently, they established a state at the foot of Mount Qi.
King Danfu can be said to have been able to preserve life.
Even if wealthy and noble,
he would not harm his body for the sake of nourishment;
even if poor and lowly,
he would not burden his body for the sake of profit.
Now, if one accepts the ancestral rank and emolument,
then one will certainly heavily lose it.
The source from which life comes has been long,
but to lightly lose it,
would that not be foolish!
Therefore, Laozi said:
"If one values the world as much as one's own body,
how can one be entrusted with the world?
To cherish oneself as the world
—how can one be entrusted with the world?"
The Master Mou, son of the ruler of Zhongshan, said to Master Zhan:
"My body is situated above the rivers and seas,
but my heart is beneath the towers of Wei.
What should be done about this?"
Master Zhan said:
"Value life.
If you value life, then you will take profit lightly."
The Master Mou, son of the ruler of Zhongshan, said:
"Even though I know this,
I still cannot overcome myself."
Master Zhan said:
"If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow it."
"If you follow it,
will your spirit have no resentment?"
"If you cannot overcome yourself but forcibly do not follow it,
this is called a grave injury.
A person with a grave injury
will not live long!"
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Knowing harmony is called constancy;
knowing constancy is called enlightenment;
increasing life is called auspiciousness;
the mind commanding the breath is called strength."
Therefore,
"Use its light,
"returns to its brightness."
King Zhuang of Chu asked Zhan He,
"How should one govern a state?"
Zhan He replied,
"Why are you clear about governing yourself,
but not clear about governing a state?"
The King of Chu said,
"I have the honor to serve the ancestral temples and the altars of the soil and grain,
and I wish to learn how to protect them."
Zhan He replied,
"I have never heard of someone governing themselves well and the state being in chaos,
nor have I ever heard of someone whose self is in chaos and the state being well-governed.
Therefore, the root lies in oneself,
and I dare not answer with what is secondary."
The King of Chu said,
"Good."
Therefore, Laozi said,
"Cultivate it in yourself,
and its virtue will be genuine."
Duke Huan was reading a book in the hall above,
and Wheelwright Bian was carving a wheel in the hall below.
He put down his mallet and chisel and asked Duke Huan,
"What book is it that you are reading, my lord?"
Duke Huan said,
"It is the book of the sages."
Wheelwright Bian said,
Wheelwright Bian said,
"Where is that person now?"
Duke Huan said,
"He is already dead."
Wheelwright Bian said,
"Then what he left behind are merely the dregs of a sage!"
Duke Huan, greatly angered, changed his expression and said,
"I am reading books,
how dare a craftsman criticize me!
If you have an explanation, then fine;
if not, you shall die."
Wheelwright Bian said,
"Indeed,
I have an explanation.
Let me try to explain it using my wheel-making:
If it's too tight,
then it's difficult and won't fit;
If it's too loose,
then it's easy but not secure.
Neither easy nor difficult,
responding to the hand,
satisfying the heart,
and being able to reach perfection,
I cannot teach it to my son,
nor can my son acquire it from me.
Therefore, having lived for sixty years,
I am still making wheels in my old age.
Now, what the sages have said,
also cherishes its essence,
and dies in poverty,
only its dregs remain!"
Therefore, Laozi said:
"The Dao that can be spoken of
is not the constant Dao.
The name that can be named
is not the constant name."
Formerly, Sicheng Zihan served as prime minister of Song.
He said to the ruler of Song:
"The safety and danger of a state,
the order and chaos of the people,
lie in Your Majesty's administration of rewards and punishments.
Now, promotions and rewards are
what the people desire;
let Your Majesty administer them.
Slaughter and punishments are
what the people resent;
allow me, your servant, to bear them."
The ruler of Song said:
"Excellent!
I shall take the credit,
and you will bear the blame.
I am confident that I will not be laughed at by the other lords."
Thereupon, the ruler of Song administered rewards, and gave punishments to Zihan.
The people of the state all knew that the authority over slaughter
rested solely with Zihan.
The high officials were intimate with him,
and the common people feared him.
Before a full year had passed since his position,
Zihan then coerced the ruler of Song and monopolized his government.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Fish should not be taken out of the deep pool;
the sharp weapons of the state cannot be shown to others."
Wang Shou carried his books and traveled,
meeting Xu Feng in Zhou.
Xu Feng said:
"Affairs
should respond to changes and move accordingly;
changes arise from the times.
Therefore, those who understand the times have no constant practices.
Books
are where words originate;
words come from knowledge,
and the knowledgeable do not hoard books."
Thereupon, Wang Shou burned his books and danced.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Excessive speech leads to exhaustion;
it is better to guard the center."
The Chief Minister Zipei requested an audience with King Zhuang for a drink,
and King Zhuang agreed.
Zipei prepared everything at the Jing Terrace,
but King Zhuang did not go.
The next day,
Zipei, barefoot, bowed
and stood facing north below the palace hall,
saying:
"In the past, Your Majesty agreed to it,
but now you did not go.
I wonder,
is it because your servant is guilty?"
King Zhuang said:
"I have heard that you are well-equipped at the Strong Terrace.
The Strong Terrace
faces Mount Liao to the south,
and borders Fanghuang to the north,
with the Jiang River on the left and the Huai River on the right.
Its pleasures make one forget death.
With my shallow virtue,
I am not worthy of such pleasure.
I fear that I would stay and not return."
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Do not display what is desirable,
so as not to disturb the mind."
When Duke Chong'er of Jin fled into exile,
he passed through Cao,
where the ruler of Cao treated him discourteously.
The wife of Xi Fuyi said to Xi Fuyi:
"The ruler has been discourteous to Duke Chong'er of Jin.
Observing his followers,
They are all virtuous men.
If you use the lords to return to the state of Jin,
they will surely attack Cao.
Why don't you first bestow favor upon them!"
Li Fu Ji gave him a pot of leftovers and added jade to it.
Chong'er accepted the leftovers but returned the jade.
When he returned to his state,
he raised an army to attack Cao,
and conquered it.
He ordered the army not to enter Li Fu Ji's village.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Bend and you will be whole,
yield and you will be straight."
King Goujian of Yue fought with Wu and was defeated,
the country was destroyed, and he nearly died,
trapped on Mount Kuaiji.
With resentment swelling in his heart,
and his spirit like a surging spring,
he selected and trained elite soldiers,
ready to rush into fire as if to extinguish it.
However, he requested to be a subject himself,
and his wife to be a concubine,
personally wielding a spear,
to lead the Wu king's horses.
As a result, he captured him in Gansui.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"That the soft overcomes the hard,
That the weak can overcome the strong is
something everyone under Heaven knows,
but no one can put into practice.”
The King of Yue personally put it into practice,
and therefore became hegemon of the Central States.
When Zhao Jianzi died,
before he was buried,
Zhongmou surrendered to Qi.
Five days after the burial,
Xiangzi raised troops and attacked it.
Before the siege was complete,
ten *zhang* of the city wall collapsed on its own.
Xiangzi struck the gong and withdrew his troops.
A military officer remonstrated, saying:
"You, sir, are punishing Zhongmou for its crime,
and the city wall collapses on its own,
it is Heaven helping us!
Why withdraw?"
Xiangzi said:
"I heard Shu Xiang say:
'A gentleman does not take advantage of others' peril,
nor does he press others into danger.'
Let them repair the city wall;
after the city is repaired, then attack it."
Zhongmou, hearing of his righteousness,
then requested to surrender.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"It is precisely because he does not contend,
that no one can contend with him."
Duke Mu of Qin said to Bo Le:
"You are old.
Do you have any family members who can be sent to find horses?"
He replied:
"A good horse
can be described in terms of its sinews and bones and its appearance.
A judge of the best horses in the world
seems to disappear, as if he has lost it,
as if he is missing something.
A horse like this
leaves no dust and smooths out wheel tracks.
My sons
are all of inferior talent;
I can tell them about good horses,
but I cannot tell them about the best horses in the world.
I have a fellow who shares burdens, ropes, and firewood gathering, named Jiu Fang Gao.
His understanding of horses
is not inferior to mine.
Please, let me introduce him."
Duke Mu met with him
and sent him to find horses.
After three months, he returned
and reported,
"I have already found a horse.
It is at Sha Qiu."
Duke Mu said,
"What kind of horse is it?"
He replied,
"A female, and yellow."
He sent someone to fetch it,
but it was a male, and black.
Duke Mu was displeased,
and summoned Bo Le to ask him, saying,
"A failure!
The one you sent to find the horse,
as for the appearance,
even male and female he can't distinguish,
how could he possibly know horses!"
Bo Le sighed deeply, saying,
"Has it come to this!
This is precisely why there are thousands of subjects and yet none worth counting.
What Yin (the one sent) observes,
is the heavenly mechanism.
He grasps the essence and forgets the coarse details,
he focuses on the inside and forgets the outside,
he sees what is to be seen and doesn't see what is not to be seen,
he looks at what is to be looked at and neglects what is not to be looked at.
What he is assessing,
is something more valuable than the horse itself."
When the horse arrived, it was indeed a thousand-li horse.
Therefore, Laozi said,
"The greatest straightness appears crooked,
the greatest skill appears clumsy."
Wu Qi became the Ling Yin (Prime Minister) of Chu.
He went to Wei
and asked Qu Yijiu, saying:
"The king does not know of Qi's unworthiness,
yet appointed me as Ling Yin.
Sir, please observe how Qi will conduct himself."
Qu Zi said:
"What do you intend to do?"
Wu Qi said:
"I intend to diminish the ranks of Chu and equalize their stipulated salaries,
reduce the excess of some to appease the deficiencies of others,
sharpen armor and weapons,
and seize opportunities to compete for advantage in the world."
Qu Zi said:
"I seem to have heard that,
in the past, those skilled at governing a state
do not change its old ways
nor alter its norms.
Now you intend to diminish the ranks of Chu and equalize their stipulated salaries,
reduce the excess of some to appease the deficiencies of others,
this is changing its old ways
and altering its norms.
Those who do this will not benefit!
I seem to have heard it said:
'Anger
is acting against virtue;
weapons
weapons of ill omen,
contention,
are what people abandon."
Now you secretly plot against virtue,
delight in using weapons of ill omen,
and govern that which people abandon.
This is the height of perversity.
Moreover, you used the troops of Lu,
and it was not fitting that you should succeed against Qi,
yet you did succeed.
You used the troops of Wei,
and it was not fitting that you should succeed against Qin,
yet you did succeed.
It seems as if I have heard that
unless it is a troublemaker,
disaster cannot be achieved.
I have always been perplexed that our king, who so often acts contrary to the way of Heaven
and violates human principles,
has not yet encountered disaster.
It seems he is waiting for you, Master."
Wu Qi, greatly alarmed, said,
"Is there still a way to change?"
Quzi said,
"One who has completed the punishment
cannot be changed.
You would do better to cherish love and earnestly practice it."
Laozi said,
"Blunt its sharpness,
Loosen its entanglements,
temper its brilliance,
and become one with its dust."
When Jin attacked Chu,
they retreated three *she* without stopping.
A high official requested to attack them,
but King Zhuang said,
"In the time of my late father,
Jin did not attack Chu.
Now that Jin attacks Chu during my reign,
it is my fault.
How can I disgrace all of you, my high officials?"
The high official said,
"In the time of my predecessors,
Jin did not attack Chu.
Now that Jin attacks Chu during my service,
this is my sin.
I beg the king to attack them."
King Zhuang bowed his head and wept, his tears soaking his robe,
then rose and bowed to the high officials.
When the Jin people heard this, they said,
"The ruler and his ministers are contending to take the blame upon themselves,
and moreover, the ruler humbles himself before his ministers;
we cannot attack them."
They turned their army around at night and returned home.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"He who can bear the dirt of the nation
This is what it means to be the master of the state."
During the time of Duke Jing of Song,
Mars was in the constellation of the Heart.
The Duke was afraid
and summoned Ziwei to ask him about it,
saying,
"Mars is in the Heart constellation,
what does this mean?"
Ziwei said,
"Mars is
a celestial punishment;
the Heart constellation
is the territory of Song,
disaster will befall the ruler.
However,
it can be transferred to the chief minister."
The Duke said,
"The chief minister
is the one I employ to govern the state,
and to transfer death to him is
inauspicious.
I, your subject, will bear it myself."
Ziwei said,
"It can be transferred to the people."
The Duke said,
"If the people die,
who would I be ruler over?
I would rather die alone!"
Ziwei said,
"It can be transferred to the harvest."
The Duke said,
"The harvest
is the life of the people.
If the year is one of famine,
the people will surely die.
If, as a ruler, I want to kill my people in order to save myself,
who would consider me their ruler?
It is that my life is indeed already exhausted;
do not speak further!"
Ziwei turned and ran,
facing north and bowing twice, saying,
"I dare to congratulate you, my lord!
Heaven dwells on high but listens to the low.
You, my lord, have spoken three times as a ruler should,
Heaven will surely reward you three times.
Tonight, the stars will surely shift three houses,
extending your life by twenty-one years."
The Duke said,
"How do you know this?"
He replied,
"You, my lord, have spoken three times as a ruler should,
therefore there will be three rewards.
The stars will surely shift three houses,
each house consisting of seven stars.
Each star shift represents one year,
"Three times seven is twenty-one,"
"therefore, your servant says that Your Majesty will live for twenty-one more years."
"Let your servant lie prostrate beneath Your Majesty to observe it."
"If the star does not move,"
"your servant asks to be put to death."
The Duke said,
"Agreed."
That very night,
the star indeed shifted its position three times.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"He who can accept the misfortunes of the state,
is called the king of all under Heaven."
Formerly,
when Gongsun Long was in Zhao,
he said to his disciples:
"If a man has no ability,
Long cannot associate with him."
A guest wearing coarse cloth and a rope belt came to see him, saying:
"Your servant can shout."
Gongsun Long, turning to his disciples, said:
"Do we have anyone among our followers who can shout?"
They replied:
"We do not."
Gongsun Long said:
"Add him to the register of disciples."
Several days later,
he went to persuade the King of Yan.
Reaching the riverbank,
and the boat being in a distant bend,
he had the man who was good at shouting call it.
With one shout, the boat came.
Therefore, the sage's way of conducting himself in the world
is not to reject men with skill and ability.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"There are no useless people,
there are no useless things,
this is called inheriting the light."
Zi Fa attacked Cai,
and overran it.
King Xuan met him with a suburban welcome,
arrayed a hundred *qing* of fields, and enfeoffed him with the ceremonial jade tablet.
Zi Fa declined to accept it,
saying:
"Governing the state and establishing policies,
and the feudal lords entering as guests,
this is the virtue of the ruler.
Issuing commands and decrees,
and the army not yet joined, yet the enemy flees,
this is the might of the general.
That soldiers arrayed in battle conquer the enemy,
this is the power of the common people.
To take their rank and salary based on the merit and labor of the people,
is not the way of benevolence and righteousness."
Therefore, he declined and did not accept it.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Achieve merit and do not dwell on it.
Precisely because you do not dwell on it,
it will not leave you."
Duke Wen of Jin attacked Yuan,
and set a three-day deadline with his officers.
After three days, Yuan did not surrender,
and Duke Wen ordered the army to withdraw.
A military officer said:
"Yuan will surrender in no more than a day or two."
The Duke said:
"I did not know that Yuan could not be taken in three days,
but I made a promise to my officers.
To not stop after exhausting (the agreed upon time),
to break faith in order to obtain Yuan,
I will not do it."
The people of Yuan heard this and said:
"Having a ruler like this,
how can we not surrender?"
And so they surrendered.
The people of Wen heard of this,
and also requested to surrender.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Profound and dark,
within it there is essence.
This essence is very real,
within it there is trustworthiness."
Therefore,
"Fine words can buy respect,
fine deeds can win people over."
Gongyi Xiu was the prime minister of Lu and
had a fondness for fish.
The entire state offered him fish,
but Gongyi Zi refused to accept them.
His disciples asked,
"Master, you are fond of fish,
yet you do not accept them.
Why is that?"
He replied,
"It is precisely because I am fond of fish
that I do not accept them.
If I accept fish and am dismissed from my position as prime minister,
even if I am fond of fish,
I will not be able to provide myself with fish.
If I do not accept fish and am not dismissed from my position as prime minister,
then I will be able to provide myself with fish for a long time."
This shows a clear understanding of acting for others and for oneself.
Therefore, Laozi said,
"Put oneself last and one will be first,
disregard oneself and one will be preserved.
Is it not because of their selflessness?
Therefore, they can achieve their own (goals)."
It is also said:
"Knowing contentment avoids disgrace."
The old man of Fox Hill said to Sun Shuao:
"People have three grievances,
do you know them?"
Sun Shuao said:
"What are they?"
He replied:
"Those with high rank are envied by scholars;
those with high office are disliked by their ruler;
those with generous emolument are resented."
Sun Shuao said:
"The higher my rank,
the lower my ambition;
the greater my office,
the smaller my heart;
the more generous my emolument,
the broader my giving.
Can I avoid these three grievances in this way?"
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Therefore, nobility must take humility as its root,
height must take the low as its base."
The Grand Commander who hammered hooks was eighty years old,
yet he did not lose his hook-hammering skills.
The Grand Marshal said:
"Are you skillful?
Or do you possess the Way?"
He replied:
"I have something I adhere to.
When I was twenty years old, I loved forging hooks.
Regarding other things, I saw nothing.
Only hooks did I observe."
Therefore, those who employ it
must rely on its non-use,
and thereby obtain its use through its strength.
How much more so for those who hold onto non-use?
What thing would not be benefited by it!
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Those who engage in the Way
become one with the Way."
King Wen cultivated his virtue and practiced good governance.
In three years, two-thirds of the empire submitted to him.
Zhou heard of this and worried, saying:
"If I rise early and retire late,
competing with him in conduct,
then I will suffer in mind and toil in body.
If I let him be and leave him alone,
I fear he will attack me alone."
Marquis Chong Hu said:
"The Earl of Zhou, Chang, is benevolent, righteous, and skilled in planning;
his eldest son, Fa, is brave and resolute;
his middle son, Dan, is respectful, frugal, and knows the times.
If we follow them,
we will be unable to bear the consequences.
If we let them be and pardon them,
our own lives will surely be in danger.
Though the hat is worn,
it must still be worn on the head.
Before he achieves his aim,
please plan for it!"
Thereupon, Qu Shang detained King Wen in Youli.
Then San Yisheng used a thousand gold pieces to seek rare and strange treasures of the world,
obtaining a Zouyu,
a chariot of Jisi horses,
a hundred artisans in dark jade,
a hundred strings of large cowrie shells,
black leopards,
yellow bears,
blue wild dogs,
and a thousand sets of white tiger striped skins,
which he presented to Zhou,
using Fei Zhong as an intermediary.
Zhou saw them and was pleased,
and released him,
slaughtering an ox and bestowing it upon him.
King Wen returned,
and then made a jade gate,
built the Lingtai Terrace,
selected young girls,
They struck the bells and drums
to await the errors of Zhou.
Zhou heard of this
and said,
"The Earl of Zhou, Chang, has changed his ways and altered his conduct;
I have nothing to worry about!"
Thereupon, he made the "pao ge" (a heated bronze pillar used for torture),
dissected Bigan,
cut open pregnant women,
and killed those who remonstrated.
King Wen then carried out his plan.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"Knowing its glory,
guard its disgrace,
and be the valley of the world."
King Cheng asked Yin Yi about government, saying:
"What virtuous conduct should I practice
so that the people will be close to their superiors?"
He replied:
"Employ them at the right times
and treat them with respect and obedience."
The King said:
"What is the extent of that?"
He said:
"Like approaching a deep abyss,
like treading on thin ice."
The King said:
"Are you afraid?
Of the king's men!"
Yin Yi replied,
"Within heaven and earth,
within the four seas,
if they are good, then they are what I nourish;
if they are not good, then they are my enemies.
In the past, the ministers of Xia
and Shang turned against Jie
and Zhou and became ministers to Tang
and Wu. The people of Suisha all attacked their own rulers and returned to Shennong.
This is something the world clearly understands.
How can there be no fear?"
Therefore, Laozi said,
"What people fear,
one cannot but fear."
The followers of Zhi asked Zhi,
"Does a robber also have a Dao?"
Zhi said,
"Why would he not have a Dao!
To be able to guess and hit the hidden stash is
Sageliness;
to enter first is
Courage;
to exit last is
Righteousness;
to divide equally is
Benevolence;
to know what is permissible and what is not is
Wisdom.
If these five are not all possessed,
and one can still become a great robber,
there is no such person in the world."
From this, it can be seen that
the heart of a thief must rely on the way of the sage before it can be put into action.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"Abandon sagacity and discard wisdom,
and the people will benefit a hundredfold."
The Chu general Zi Fa was fond of seeking out men skilled in techniques and the Way.
A man skilled in theft from Chu went to see him, saying:
"I have heard that you, sir, are seeking men skilled in techniques and the Way.
I am a thief in the Chu market,
and I wish to offer my skills to lead one soldier."
When Zi Fa heard of this,
his robe was not fully fastened,
his cap was not properly adjusted,
and he went out to meet and treat him with courtesy.
His attendants remonstrated, saying:
"A thief
is a robber to all under heaven.
Why do you treat him with courtesy?"
The lord said:
"This is something you attendants cannot understand."
Not long after,
Qi raised an army to attack Chu.
Zifa led the army to oppose them,
and the army retreated three times.
The virtuous and talented senior officials of Chu all exhausted their plans and devoted their sincerity,
but the Qi army grew even stronger.
Thereupon, a petty thief from the market advanced and requested,
"I have a small skill,
and I wish to employ it for you, my lord."
Zifa said,
"Agreed."
Without asking his plan, he sent him off.
The thief then went out at night, untied the Qi general's tent canopy, and presented it [to Zifa].
Zifa then had someone return it,
saying,
"A soldier gathering firewood
found the general's tent,
and has been ordered to return it to you, sir."
The next night, he went again and took his pillow.
Zifa again had someone return it.
The next night, he went again and took his hairpin.
Zifa again had someone return it.
The Qi army heard of this
and were greatly alarmed.
The general and his officers discussed it, saying,
"If we do not leave today,
the Chu army will likely take our heads."
So they turned their army around and left.
Therefore, skills, no matter how small, are never insignificant;
It just depends on how the ruler employs them.
Therefore, Laozi said:
"The unwholesome person
is the resource of the wholesome person."
Yan Hui said to Zhongni (Confucius):
"I, Hui, have improved."
Zhongni said:
"What do you mean?"
He replied:
"I have forgotten the rites and music."
Zhongni said:
"Acceptable,
but still not there."
On another day, he saw him again and
said:
"I, Hui, have improved."
Zhongni said:
"What do you mean?"
He replied:
"I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness."
Zhongni said:
"Acceptable,
but still not there."
On another day, he saw him again and
said:
"I have achieved sitting in oblivion."
Zhongni gravely said:
"What is 'sitting in oblivion'?"
Yan Hui said:
"Discarding limbs,
rejecting cleverness,
separating from form and abandoning knowledge,
penetrating to the transformations and becoming one with them,
this is what is called 'sitting in oblivion.'"
Zhongni (Confucius) said:
"Penetrating means there is no goodness,
transforming means there is no constancy.
And if you, sir, recommend the worthy,
I, Qiu, would like to follow after them."
Therefore, Laozi said:
"When carrying the soul and embracing oneness,
can you keep from departing from it?
Concentrating your qi to the utmost softness,
can you become like an infant?"
Duke Mu of Qin raised an army,
intending to attack Zheng by surprise.
Jian Shu said:
"It is not permissible.
I have heard that one who attacks a state by surprise
with chariots should not travel more than a hundred li,
and with infantry should not travel more than thirty li,
because their plans have not yet had time to leak out,
their armor and weapons have not yet become worn and blunted,
their provisions have not yet become scarce and exhausted,
The people have not yet recovered from their hardship.
They all arrived relying on their high morale and great strength,
therefore, they were able to be formidable when confronting the enemy.
Now, they are traveling thousands of *li* (Chinese miles),
and repeatedly crossing the territories of various lords,
to attack a state.
Your servant does not know if this is advisable.
Your lord should seriously reconsider it!"
Duke Mu did not listen.
Jian Shu saw the army off,
dressed in mourning clothes and wept for them.
The army then departed,
