The sage guards what he already possesses,
not seeking what he has not yet obtained.
Seeking what he has not yet obtained,
then what he possesses will be lost;
cultivating what he already has,
then what he desires will arrive.
Therefore, one who uses troops
first makes oneself invincible,
in order to await the enemy's vulnerability;
one who governs a country
first makes oneself impregnable,
in order to await the enemy's vulnerability.
Shun cultivated himself at Mount Li, and the world followed and transformed;
King Wen cultivated virtue in Qi and Zhou, and the world changed its customs.
If you make Shun pursue the benefits of the world,
and forget the way of cultivating himself,
he still wouldn't be able to protect himself,
how could he possess even a foot of land!
Therefore, if governance is not firmly established in a state of non-chaos,
and one acts as a ruler to govern,
it will surely be dangerous;
if conduct is not firmly established in a state of faultlessness,
and one eagerly seeks fame,
one will surely be thwarted.
There is no greater fortune than being without misfortune,
there is no finer benefit than being without loss.
The nature of action
is that if it doesn't diminish, it increases;
if it doesn't succeed, it fails;
if it's not beneficial, it is harmful;
all are dangerous,
guiding them is perilous.
Therefore, Qin conquered the Rong but was defeated at Yao,
Chu conquered the various Xia states but was defeated at Baiju.
Therefore, the Way cannot be used to encourage the pursuit of benefit,
but can be used to find peace in avoiding harm.
Therefore, there is often no misfortune,
but not often fortune;
there is often no fault,
but not often merit.
The sage has no deliberation,
Do not establish stores;
Those who come, do not welcome;
Those who leave, do not send off.
Though people go east, west, south, and north,
Stand alone in the center.
Therefore, dwell amidst the crookedness of the masses,
And not lose your straightness;
The world is all flowing,
But you alone do not leave your altar.
Therefore, do not act for the sake of being liked,
Do not avoid being disliked,
Follow the Way of Heaven;
Do not be a beginner,
Do not be self-opinionated,
Follow the principles of Heaven.
Do not plan beforehand,
Do not waste time,
Make an appointment with Heaven;
To do good is to be observed;
Do not seek to gain,
Do not decline blessings,
to do bad is to be criticized.
Observation breeds reproach;
Follow the rules of Heaven.
criticism breeds trouble.
Do not seek what you do not have,
Therefore, the principles of the Way cannot be used to advance and seek fame,
Do not lose what you have obtained,
Internally there are no strange misfortunes,
but can be used to retreat and cultivate oneself;
Externally there are no strange blessings.
they cannot be used to gain profit,
Misfortune and blessing do not arise,
but can be used to avoid harm.
How can there be human-caused harm!
Therefore, the sage does not seek fame through action,
nor does he seek praise through wisdom and insight.
He models himself on nature,
and does not interfere.
Deliberations cannot overcome fate,
actions cannot overcome virtue,
and affairs cannot overcome the Way.
Those who act may not succeed;
those who seek may not obtain.
Man has limitations,
but the Way is all-encompassing.
To contend with the Way is ominous.
Therefore, the *Book of Poetry* says:
"Unknowing and unperceiving,
follow the patterns of the Lord on High."
To have wisdom but not act is to be on the same path as the unwise;
to have ability but not be engaged in affairs is to have the same virtue as the incapable.
to have ability but take no initiative is
to have the same virtue as the incapable.
Their wisdom is such that
only when someone tells them to act
do they realize it is time to move;
their ability is such that
only when someone makes them do something
do they realize it is time to act.
Having wisdom as if without wisdom,
having ability as if without ability,
this is because principle and reason are taken as the standard.
Therefore, if their achievements cover the world,
they do not flaunt their excellence.
If their beneficence extends to later generations,
they do not claim its fame.
When principle and reason prevail, then human effort is extinguished.
Fame and the Dao cannot both be illustrious.
If people love fame, then the Dao will not be employed.
If the Dao prevails over people, then fame will cease.
The Dao and people compete for growth.
Those who make people illustrious
suppress the Dao.
If people are made illustrious and the Dao is suppressed,
then danger is not far off.
Therefore, if the world has a reputation for sagehood,
then flattery of the Dao will increase daily.
Those who desire to occupy fame must do good deeds.
Those who desire to do good deeds must create affairs.
When something arises, one abandons the public and inclines toward the private,
forsaking principle and relying on oneself.
Desiring to be praised for doing good,
and to establish a reputation for being virtuous,
then governance does not follow established practices,
and actions do not accord with the times.
If governance does not follow established practices,
then there will be much blame;
if actions do not accord with the times,
then there will be no merit.
With much blame and little merit,
unable to compensate for it,
then one rashly speaks, hoping to hit the mark,
and rashly acts, hoping to succeed.
Even if one achieves success,
it is not enough to offset the blame;
if one fails in an endeavor,
it is enough to ruin oneself.
Therefore, to be cautious in doing good is like being cautious in doing wrong,
and is close to the Dao.
It is not that the world lacks trustworthy people;
when faced with goods and dividing wealth, they invariably draw lots to determine the shares,
considering that the fairness of those with intentions
is not as good as that of those without intentions.
It is not that the world lacks incorruptible people;
however, those guarding valuable treasures invariably close the door and keep the seal intact,
considering that the integrity of those with desires
It is not as good as being without desires.
People resent others who point out their flaws,
but appreciate a mirror that reflects their ugliness.
If a person can interact with things without involving the self,
then they will be free from burdens.
Gongsun Long was brilliant in rhetoric but bartered his reputation;
Deng Xi was skilled in debate but disrupted the law;
Su Qin was good at persuasion but lost his life.
If following their way, goodness has no principle;
if following their reasoning, skill has no reputation.
Therefore, those who use skill to contend with strength
begin in the light
and usually end in darkness;
those who use cleverness to govern a state
begin with order
and usually end in chaos.
To make water flow downward,
who cannot manage it?
To force it upward,
only the skillful can do it.
Therefore, if refinement surpasses substance, substance is obscured;
if crooked skillfulness prevails, righteousness is blocked.
Virtue can be used to cultivate oneself,
but cannot be used to make people tyrannical;
the Way can be used to govern oneself,
and cannot allow people to be thrown into disorder.
Even if one possesses the treasures of the wise and the sage,
if one does not encounter a time of violent upheaval,
one can preserve oneself,
but one cannot become a hegemon or king.
Tang and Wu became kings
because they encountered the tyranny of Jie and
Zhou.
Jie and Zhou were not tyrannical because of the virtue of Tang and
Wu;
Tang and Wu encountered the tyranny of Jie and
Zhou and thus became kings.
Therefore, even a wise king
must await his opportunity.
"Encounter" means
to be able to meet the times and seize them;
it is not something that can be sought and achieved through knowledge and ability.
The superior man cultivates his conduct and makes goodness nameless,
practices charity and makes benevolence without ostentation.
Therefore, the scholar practices goodness without knowing where the goodness comes from,
the people receive benefits without knowing where the benefits originate.
Thus, there is non-action and yet self-governance.
If goodness is ostentatious, then scholars will compete for fame;
if profit has a source, then the people will compete for merit.
When these two compete, strife arises,
and even if there are wise men,
they will not be able to govern.
Therefore, the sage conceals traces of doing good,
and rests fame in doing benevolence.
Seeking external alliances for aid,
and serving the powerful for security,
is not as good as governing internally and awaiting the opportune time.
In general, serving others,
is not achieved through treasures and wealth,
but rather through humble words.
Serving with jade and silk,
will deplete resources and leave desires unsatiated;
humbling oneself and using gentle words,
will result in explanation but unresolved relationships;
imposing constraints and oaths,
will lead to agreements being broken at any moment;
Even if one cedes the smallest amounts of territory to serve others,
without a way to rely on oneself,
it is not enough to ensure preservation.
If one truly abandons the strategy of external alliances,
and carefully cultivates internal affairs,
exhausts the land's potential to increase accumulation,
encourages the people to risk death to strengthen the city walls,
with the ruler and subjects of one mind,
sharing the same will,
guarding the state together,
with the people willing to die and not abandon,
then those seeking fame will not attack the blameless,
and those seeking profit will not attack the difficult to conquer.
This must be the way to wholeness.
The people have principles by which they share the same path,
and laws that they jointly observe.
But righteousness cannot necessarily bind them together,
and power cannot necessarily hold them in place.
Therefore, a ruler is established to unify the people.
If the ruler holds fast to unity, there is order;
if he is inconstant, there is chaos.
The way of the ruler
is not about actively doing things,
but about non-action.
What is meant by non-action?
The wise do not use their position to engage in affairs,
the brave do not use their position to be violent,
the benevolent do not use their position to show favor.
This can be called non-action.
Now, non-action leads to the attainment of unity.
This unity
is the foundation of all things,
and the way to be invincible.
Generally, human nature is such that
in youth they are recklessly unrestrained,
in adulthood they are violently strong,
and in old age they are greedy for profit.
If a single person undergoes so many changes,
how much more so when the ruler frequently changes the laws,
and the state frequently changes rulers!
People use their positions to facilitate their likes and dislikes,
and the crooked paths taken by subordinates become too numerous to manage.
Therefore, a ruler’s single mistake can cause chaos
that is even worse than having no ruler at all.
Thus, the *Book of Poetry* says:
“Do not exceed, do not forget,
follow the old rules.”
This is what it means.
If the ruler is fond of wisdom,
then he will double his own time and rely on himself,
abandoning calculations and using deliberation.
The things of the world are vast, but wisdom is shallow.
Using the shallow to provide for the vast,
there has never been anyone who could do that.
Relying solely on his own wisdom,
he will surely make many mistakes.
Therefore, being fond of wisdom is
a path to exhaustion.
If the ruler is fond of courage,
then he will underestimate the enemy and neglect preparations,
rely on himself alone and refuse assistance.
Using the strength of one person
to resist a strong enemy,
not relying on the masses but exclusively using his own talent and strength,
he will surely be unable to withstand it.
Therefore, being fond of courage is
a dangerous path.
Favoring giving
then there is no fixed distribution.
If the ruler's distribution is not fixed,
then the expectations of those below will have no end.
If one levies taxes excessively,
filling the treasury,
then one makes oneself an enemy of the people.
To take little and give much,
has never occurred.
Therefore, favoring giving
is the way to invite resentment.
Benevolence, wisdom, courage, and strength
are the beautiful talents of men,
but none of them are sufficient to govern the world.
From this perspective,
the insufficiency of worthies and the able is clear,
and that the Way and methods are worthy to be followed is apparent.
The sage overcomes his heart,
the multitude overcomes their desires.
The gentleman acts with upright qi,
the petty man acts with deviant qi.
That which inwardly accords with one's nature,
outwardly conforms to righteousness,
acts according to principle,
and is not attached to things,
is upright qi.
To indulge in flavors,
Indulging in sounds and sights,
being driven by joy and anger,
not considering the consequences,
this is corrupting Qi.
Corrupting Qi and correct Qi injure each other,
desire and nature harm each other,
they cannot both stand.
One is established, the other is discarded.
Therefore, the sage diminishes desires and follows nature.
The eye loves colors,
the ear loves sounds,
the mouth loves flavors,
they receive and delight in them.
Not knowing what is beneficial or harmful,
this is desire.
Eating them does not bring peace to the body,
hearing them does not accord with the Dao,
seeing them is not convenient for one's nature.
When the three gates (eyes, ears, mouth) clash,
the one that uses righteousness as a constraint is
the mind.
Cutting off a boil is not painless,
drinking poison is not bitter,
but people do it because
it is beneficial to the body.
Drinking water when thirsty is not pleasant,
eating a large meal when hungry is not satisfying,
but people do not do it because
it harms one's nature.
These four things,
the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth do not know what to take or discard,
the mind controls them,
so that each gets its proper place.
From this perspective,
it is clear that desires cannot be overcome.
In general, governing the body and nourishing the nature
requires moderation in rest and dwelling,
properness in eating and drinking,
harmony in joy and anger,
and convenience in activity and stillness,
so that what is within oneself is obtained,
and evil influences will naturally not arise.
Is this not better than worrying about the rise of internal disorders and blemishes,
or the breaking out of sores and ulcers, and then preparing for them in advance?
A cauldron containing boiling beef, flies and gnats dare not enter;
a jade ornament from Mount Kunlun, dust and dirt cannot defile it.
The sage has no heart for rejecting, and so his heart has no ugliness;
he has no heart for seizing beauty, and so beauty is not lost.
Therefore, in sacrifices, he thinks of his ancestors but does not seek blessings;
in entertaining guests, he cultivates reverence but does not think of virtue.
Only those who do not seek are able to possess.
Those who occupy high positions
do so because they have impartiality and no private opinions,
therefore they are called honored,
He is not praised as virtuous.
One who possesses a great territory
relies on consistent methods and lacks controlling strategies.
Therefore, he is called "level" and
not praised as wise.
Internally, there are no violent incidents to alienate the people,
and externally, there are no displays of virtue to incite jealousy among the feudal lords.
The rituals between superiors and inferiors
are followed without deviation,
and yet those who discuss him find nothing remarkable to observe.
This is what is meant by "hiding without form."
If he did not hide without form,
how could he possess form?
What the Three Dynasties followed
was adaptation to circumstance.
Therefore, Yu regulated the rivers,
adapting to the nature of water.
Hou Ji sowed seeds and planted grains,
adapting to the nature of the land.
Tang and Wu quelled tyranny and rebellion,
adapting to the timing of events.
Therefore, the world can be attained but not seized by force.
Hegemony can be received but not sought.
Rely on wisdom, and people will contend with you.
Rely on force, and people will struggle against you.
There has never been a ruler who could make people lack wisdom,
but there have been those who could prevent people from using their wisdom for their own benefit.
There has never been a case of someone being deprived of strength,
but there are cases of people being unable to apply their strength to themselves.
These two situations are often observed over time.
Therefore, if a ruler's virtue is not apparent,
the feudal lords will not be prepared;
if a ruler's lack of virtue is not apparent,
then the common people will not complain.
If the common people do not complain, then the resources of the people can be obtained;
if the feudal lords are unprepared,
then the opportune moment of the world can be seized.
Matters are undertaken in accordance with the multitude,
accomplishments are achieved in accordance with the timing,
the sage has no (personal claim) in them.
Therefore, Lao Tzu said:
"The tiger has nowhere to put its claws,
the rhinoceros has nowhere to put its horn."
This is probably what he meant.
The drum does not hoard its sound,
therefore it is able to produce sound;
the mirror does not predetermine its form,
therefore it is able to reflect form.
Metal and stone have sound,
but they will not sound unless struck;
pipes and flutes have tones,
but they will not sound unless blown.
The sage keeps (his talents) within,
and does not initiate actions for things,
One responds with a plan when an event arises,
and reacts accordingly when an object arrives.
To adorn the exterior harms the interior,
and to indulge the emotions injures the spirit.
To focus on the outward appearance obscures the inner substance.
One who never forgets for even a moment that he is a worthy man
will surely be troubled by his nature.
One who does not forget to maintain a proper appearance even within a hundred paces
will surely burden his form.
Therefore, beautiful feathers and wings injure the skeleton,
and beautiful branches and leaves harm the roots.
To be able to achieve both kinds of beauty,
is something that does not exist in the world.
Heaven has light,
yet it does not worry about the people's darkness.
The people bore doors and carve windows,
and obtain light for themselves.
Earth has resources,
yet it does not worry about the people's poverty.
The people cut down trees and clear grass,
and obtain wealth for themselves.
The highest virtue of the Way is like a mound or mountain,
towering and immovable,
serving as a landmark for travelers.
It rectifies itself and suffices for all things,
not acting as an intermediary for others.
Those who use it also do not receive its virtue,
Therefore, tranquility allows for longevity.
Heaven and Earth give nothing,
therefore, nothing is taken away.
The sun and moon possess no virtue,
therefore, there is no resentment.
Those who rejoice in gains will surely have much to complain about.
Those who delight in giving are adept at seizing.
Only those who obliterate their traces in non-action and follow the naturalness of Heaven and Earth,
are capable of surpassing principle and having no attachment to fame.
When fame arises, the Dao cannot be practiced.
When the Dao is practiced, people have no status.
Therefore, praise gives rise to slander,
and when good is visible, evil follows it.
Profit is the beginning of harm,
and fortune is the precursor to misfortune.
Only those who do not seek profit are without harm,
and only those who do not seek fortune are without misfortune.
A lord who seeks hegemony will surely lose his lordship,
and a hegemon who seeks kingship will surely lose his hegemony.
Therefore, the wholeness (preservation) of a state is the constant,
while hegemony and kingship are merely temporary.
The life of the body is the constant,
while wealth and honor are merely temporary.
One who can avoid harming his state for the sake of all under heaven,
and avoid harming his own body for the sake of his state,
is one to whom all under heaven can be entrusted.
Those who do not understand,
relinquish what they already possess,
and seek what they have not yet obtained.
With painstaking effort and anxious worry,
they act according to twisted reasons.
When fortune arrives, they rejoice;
when misfortune arrives, they are afraid.
Their spirit is weary from planning,
their wisdom is hasty in action.
Misfortune and fortune sprout forth,
and they regret it not throughout their lives.
What they themselves have created
instead causes them to worry about others.
If not happy, then worried;
their center is never at peace.
Holding to something without examination,
this is called a madman.
If a ruler favors benevolence,
then those without merit are rewarded,
and those with crime are released.
If he favors punishment,
then those with merit are discarded,
and those without guilt are executed.
But if there is no favoritism,
then execution causes no resentment,
and bestowing brings no gratitude.
Holding to standards and following the line,
the self is not involved in affairs.
Like Heaven and Earth,
what does he not cover and support?
Therefore, the one who unites and harmonizes is the ruler;
the one who controls and punishes is...
When the people have already been punished,
they have no resentment or regret;
this is called the Dao.
When the Dao prevails,
then people will have nothing to do.
The sage does not have eccentric clothing,
nor does he have strange and unusual behavior.
His clothing is not remarkable,
his behavior is not ostentatious,
his words are not debated,
He is accessible yet not flamboyant,
impoverished yet not intimidated,
honored yet not conspicuous,
hidden yet not depleted,
different yet not considered strange,
accepting and yet the same as the masses.
There is nothing to name it,
this is called "great accessibility."
Ascending and descending, bowing and yielding,
hastening and circling,
are done out of necessity;
they are not what one inherently possesses.
Emotions without restriction,
doing what one cannot avoid,
and not understanding the structure of it all.
How could one intentionally fabricate them?
Therefore, one who sings out of necessity
does not strive to appear sorrowful;
one who dances out of necessity
does not boast of being beautiful.
Singing and dancing without striving to appear sorrowful or beautiful
are all without rooted intention.
A skilled gambler does not desire to profit,
nor does he fear not winning.
With a calm and focused mind,
he makes throws that are accurate.
He acts according to principle.
Even if he does not necessarily win,
he will certainly gain many chips.
Why?
Victory lies in the (inherent) numbers,
and not in desire.
One who races does not greedily seek to be first,
nor does he fear being the only one in the rear.
The speed is regulated by the hand,
the control of the mind is regulated by the horse.
Although I cannot guarantee to be first,
I will certainly exhaust my strength.
Why is this?
Being first depends on fate (or destiny, number),
and not on desire.
Therefore, if you eliminate desire, fate will prevail;
if you abandon cleverness, the Way will be established.
A merchant with many ventures will become poor;
a craftsman with many skills will become impoverished;
their hearts are not unified.
Therefore, a large tree harms its branches,
a large body of water harms its depth.
Having wisdom but lacking method,
even if you drill it, you will not penetrate;
having a hundred skills but lacking a single Way,
even if you obtain something, you will not be able to keep it.
Therefore, the *Book of Poetry* says:
"The virtuous man and gentleman,
his demeanor is unified."
"His demeanor is unified,
his heart is like a knot."
The gentleman should be knotted (focused) on one thing!
Shun played a five-stringed lute,
and sang the poem "Southern Wind,"
in order to govern the world.
The Duke of Zhou did not put away delicacies right in front of him,
nor did he stop the bells and drums from playing,
in order to assist King Cheng and pacify the empire.
An ordinary man has a hundred *mu* to guard,
not having time to relax,
not moving from his post.
If one person simultaneously listens to all under heaven,
there would be days with time to spare, yet governance would be insufficient,
because they caused people to do it that way.
He who occupies the position of honor is like the corpse,
and he who guards the office is like the prayer-official and cook.
The corpse skinning the dog and roasting the pig,
even if he were able, he should not do it,
lest he should fail;
the order of dishes in the sacrificial array,
the sequence of millet and glutinous millet,
even if he knows,
he should not instruct,
even if he cannot,
it does no harm.
One who cannot pray
cannot serve as the prayer-official,
but this does no harm to his serving as the corpse;
one who cannot drive
cannot serve as the attendant,
but this does no harm to his serving as the assistant.
Therefore, the higher the position, the more relaxed the person;
the greater the office, the fewer the affairs.
For example, when tuning a zither,
though the small strings are tight,
the large strings must be loose.
Wu-wei (non-action)
is the essence of the Dao;
holding to what comes after
is the appearance of the Dao.
Using wu-wei to control yu-wei (action)
is a technique (術);
using holding to what comes after to control what comes before
is a method (數).
Relying on technique leads to strength;
being discerning in method leads to peace.
Now, suppose you give someone Bian He's jade,
the one who has not yet received it
is prior (先);
seeking and obtaining it,
even if resented, will not be opposed because that is
posterior (後).
Three people live together,
two people are arguing,
each arguer believes they are right,
and they cannot listen to each other.
Even if the third person is foolish,
they will certainly resolve the dispute from the side,
not because of intelligence,
but because of non-contention.
If two people are fighting,
and a weak person is on the side,
helping one person will lead to victory,
saving one person will lead to exemption (from harm).
Even if the fighters are strong,
they will certainly be controlled by the weak person.
not through courage,
but through not fighting.
From this perspective,
the later controlling the former,
the still conquering the restless,
is a matter of principle.
Doubling the path and abandoning principle,
to seek accidental encounters,
changing the constant and altering the old,
to knowingly seek obstruction,
if it is wrong, then blame oneself,
if it is right, then consider it luck.
Acting blindly and changing wrongly,
never realizing it in the end,
this is called madness.
Yielding when there is misfortune,
becoming full when there is fortune,
regretting when there is fault,
becoming arrogant when there is merit,
and consequently not knowing to revert (to the proper state),
this is called madness.
Circles follow the compass,
squares follow the set-square.
Marching forms patterns like animals,
halting forms orderly formations.
This can be used to command a few,
but not to command many.
Smartweed grows in rows,
jugs and pots have embankments.
Measure the grain before pounding it,
count the rice before cooking it.
This can be used to manage a household,
but not to govern a state.
Wash the cup before eating,
cleanse the goblet before drinking.
Wash before presenting food,
This can be used to care for the elderly in the family,
but not to feast the entire army.
It is only with ease that one can manage great affairs;
it is only with simplicity that one can unite the masses.
Great music must be easy,
great ceremony must be simple.
Ease is how it accords with Heaven,
simplicity is how it accords with Earth.
Great music has no resentment,
great ceremony has no reprimands.
Within the four seas,
nothing is not connected,
Therefore, one is capable of becoming an emperor.
When the heart is burdened with worries,
even broad beds and comfortable mats cannot bring peace,
wild rice and well-fed beef cannot taste sweet,
and the sounds of zithers, lutes, and reed organs cannot bring joy.
When troubles are resolved and worries are gone,
then food tastes sweet, sleep is peaceful,
dwelling is comfortable, and recreation is joyful.
From this, we can see that
the nature of people has something to derive joy from,
and death has something to be mourned for.
Now, to strive for what the nature cannot enjoy,
and to harm what the nature finds joy in,
therefore, even if one possesses all the wealth under heaven,
and holds the esteemed position of the Son of Heaven,
one cannot escape being a person of sorrow.
The nature of all people
delights in tranquility and hates anxiety,
delights in ease and hates labor.
When the heart is constantly without desires,
it can be called tranquil;
when the body is constantly without affairs,
it can be called at ease.
Letting the heart roam in tranquility,
letting the body be free and at ease,
and waiting for the decree of Heaven,
one finds joy within,
Do not be anxious about external things;
even the greatness of the world
is not enough to change your essence.
Time stealthily passes without watering your ambition.
Therefore, even if humble, you are like nobility;
even if poor, you are like wealth.
The Great Way has no form;
Great Benevolence has no favorites;
Great Eloquence is without sound;
Great Integrity is not covetous.
Great Courage is not boastful.
Do not abandon these five qualities,
and you will be close to achieving enlightenment.
An army with too many orders becomes chaotic;
wine with too many restrictions leads to argument.
Chaos results in surrender and defeat;
argument leads to mutual harm.
Therefore, what begins in elegance often ends in vulgarity;
what begins in joy often ends in sorrow.
What begins simply
will surely end harmoniously.
Now, if you have fine wine and delicious food to entertain guests,
and treat them with humility and gentle words,
intending to foster harmony,
yet they compete over filling their cups,
it will instead lead to fighting.
Fighting and injuring each other,
causing three families to form grudges,
turning against what they hate –
this is the failure of wine.
The *Shi Jing* losing its lessons,
music losing its barbs,
rituals losing their responsibilities.
The *zhi* tone is not without the sound of *yu*,
the *yu* tone is not without the sound of *zhi*.
All five tones have sound,
but they are named by *zhi* and *yu*
because those tones are dominant.
Thus, benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, and courage
are what the sages are fully equipped with,
yet they all establish a single name,
referring to that which is greatest.
Yang *qi* arises in the northeast
and ends in the southwest;

but they are not the means of creating them.
Models and standards
are things that change in accordance with the times.
Therefore, by staying in the shade of a hall, one can know the order of the sun and moon;
by seeing the ice in a bottle, one can know the cold and heat of the world.
The reasons why things influence each other are subtle;
only the sage understands them to the fullest extent.
Therefore, the drum does not participate in the five tones, but it is the master of the five tones;
water does not participate in the five flavors, but it regulates the five flavors;
the general does not participate in the affairs of the five offices, but he oversees the five offices.
Therefore, the one who can regulate the five tones
does not participate in the five tones;
the one who can regulate the five flavors
does not participate in the five flavors;
the one who can manage the affairs of the five offices
is immeasurable.
Therefore, the general's mind
is overflowing like spring,
vast and open like summer,
clear and serene like autumn,
and solid and still like winter.
He transforms in accordance with the forms [shapes, circumstances],
To shift with it according to the times.
For a shadow does not straighten a crooked object,
and an echo does not muddy a clear sound.
Observe the way in which they come,
each responds according to its strength.
Therefore, move by supporting righteousness,
act by reasoning according to principles,
conceal weaknesses and then decisively cut,
achieve success by relying on resources,
let them know where I originate but not know where I enter,
know what I raise but not know where I gather.
At the beginning, be like a fox;
therefore they will come lightly.
United, be like a rhinoceros or tiger;
therefore the enemy will flee.
When a flying bird swoops down, it lowers its head;
when a fierce beast pounces, it hides its claws.
Tigers and leopards do not expose their teeth,
and biting dogs do not show their fangs.
Therefore, the way of using troops
is to show them softness but meet them with firmness,
show them weakness but take advantage of them with strength,
act as if contracting but respond with expansion,
pretend to want to go west while showing them east,
first disobey, then unite,
first be obscure, then be clear,
like a ghost without tracks,
like water without a source.
Therefore, where one aims is not where one goes,
what one shows is not what one plans,
every action and inaction,
no one can recognize.
Like a thunderclap,
impossible to prepare for.
What is used never returns,
thus victory is utterly assured.
Communicating with the mysterious and clear,
none knows its gateway;
This is called ultimate divine efficacy.
The reason why an army is strong
is because of its willingness to die.
The reason why the people are willing to die
is because of righteousness.
The reason why righteousness can be implemented
is because of authority.
Therefore, unite them with culture,
and regulate them with military discipline;
this is called certain victory.
When authority and righteousness go hand in hand,
this is called ultimate strength.
What people enjoy
is life,
and what they hate
is death.
Yet, when facing high walls and deep moats,
with arrows and stones like rain,
or on level plains and broad marshes,
with naked blades crossing,
the soldiers strive to be the first to engage.
It is not that they take death lightly and delight in injury,
In the summer, they did not raise a canopy;
in the winter, they did not wear fur robes,
in order to gauge the heat and cold.
They did not ride through dangerous passes,
and they dismounted when crossing hills,
in order to equalize labor and leisure.
only daring to eat after the army's food is cooked,
only daring to drink after the army's wells are open,
is how one shares hunger and thirst;
in battle, always standing within range of arrows and stones,
is how one shares safety and danger.
Therefore, a good general's use of troops
is always to use accumulated virtue to strike accumulated resentment,
to use accumulated love to strike accumulated hatred.
For what reason would he not be victorious!
What the ruler seeks from the people are two things:
to seek that the people labor for him,
to desire that the people die for him.
What the people hope for from the ruler are three things:
that the hungry can be fed,
that the weary can be rested,
that the meritorious can be rewarded.
If the people fulfill their two obligations,
but the ruler fails in their three hopes,
even if the country is large,
and the people are many,
the army will still be weak.

If superiors regard subordinates as sons,
then they will surely rule the four seas.
If subordinates regard superiors as fathers,
then they will surely rectify the world.
If superiors treat subordinates as younger brothers with affection,
then it will not be difficult for them to die for them.
If those below serve those above as elder brothers,
then it will not be difficult for them to die for them.
Therefore, when fathers, sons, and brothers are enemies,
one should not fight them,
because they have accumulated kindness and bestowed favors beforehand.
Therefore, if the four horses are not in harmony,
even Zaofu cannot make them travel far.
If the bow and arrow are not in tune,
even Yi cannot guarantee a hit.
If the ruler and his ministers are at odds,
then even Sun Tzu cannot use them to face the enemy.
Therefore, one must cultivate one's government internally to accumulate virtue,
block one's shortcomings externally to establish one's authority,
and observe their labor and leisure to know their satiation and hunger.
Therefore, the battle day is fixed,
and they will look upon death as returning home.
Therefore, the general must share the same joys and hardships with his soldiers,
and share the same hunger and cold,
so their death can be fully attained.
Therefore, the good generals of ancient times
always led with their own person.

"Shuō Lín Xùn"
17.1 Using the standards of a single generation to govern the world
is like a traveler riding a boat
who, in the middle of the stream, loses his sword,
and hastily carves a mark on the side of his boat.
When the boat docks in the evening, he looks for it there.
How great is his ignorance of the categories of things!
To follow the trace of a single corner
and not know how to roam in accordance with Heaven and Earth
is the greatest of confusions.
Even if it sometimes coincides,
it is not worth valuing.
It is like a clay dragon in a year of drought
or a straw effigy during an epidemic.
At that time, they are treated as emperors.
17.2 The torn cloth of the Cáo family
is valued by ants,
but it is not the huáng jade of the Xiàhòu clan.
17.3 Without past or present,
without beginning or end,
it existed before Heaven and Earth and gave birth to Heaven and Earth.
It is extremely profound, subtle, vast, and great.
17.4 The place the foot treads is shallow,
but one walks by relying on the place not tread upon.
What knowledge knows is limited,
yet it is dependent on what it does not know in order to become clear.
17.5 A swimmer who kicks with their feet
and pushes with their hands,
not understanding the proper method,
the more they kick, the more they fail;
but when they can swim,
it's no longer about the hands and feet.
17.6 Birds fly back to their home,
rabbits run back to their burrows,
foxes die with their heads facing their mounds,
the cold is about to hover over the water,
each relies on where they were born.
17.7 Do not give a mirror to the blind,
do not give shoes to the crippled,
do not reward the people of Yuè with ceremonial caps,
for it is not of use to them.
17.8 A hammer is firmly attached to a hundred handles,
yet it cannot hammer itself;
the eye sees what is a hundred paces away,
yet it cannot see its own eyelashes.
17.9 Dogs and pigs do not choose their earthenware pots when eating,
they secretly fatten their bodies but hasten their deaths;
the phoenix soars high above a thousand *rèn*,
therefore no one can reach it.
17.10 The moon shines on the world,
yet it is eclipsed by *zhān zhū*;
the *téng shé* travels in the mist,
yet is endangered by the centipede (*jíqū*);
the crow's strength surpasses the sun,
yet it submits to the turtledove (*zhuīzhá*);
abilities have their limits.
17.11 None live shorter than a child who dies young (*shāngzǐ*),
yet Péngzǔ is considered short-lived.
17.12 A short rope cannot draw from deep wells,
a small vessel cannot contain great amounts;
it is not suited to the task.
17.13 Anger arises from non-anger,
action arises from non-action.
17.14 Observe what is formless,
and you will gain what is seen;
listen to what is soundless,
and you will gain what is heard.
17.15 The greatest flavor is not satisfying (*qiè*),
the greatest words are unadorned,
the greatest joy is without laughter,
the greatest sound is without clamor,
the great craftsman does not carve,
the great cook does not use platters,
the great warrior does not fight;
having attained the Dao, virtue follows.
